head_text.subj: BARBED WIRE AGAINST A WINTRY NIGHT SKY

text: Beyond it, more barbed wire. Ice has formed on the strand Now and then searchlight beams crisscross the pattern. As the CAMERA SLOWLY MOVES along the double fence, SUPERIMPO

A wide expanse of barren ground checkered with clusters o barracks, sectioned off into compounds by double barbed-w fences, nine feet high. Searchlights sweep over the barra the muddy ground with the snow patches, and the pine fore beyond the barbed-wire. The searchlights come from the go towers -- little guard houses elevated on poles --  interspersed along the fences.

(with an occasional  stammer) I don't know about you, but it always  make me sore when I see those war  pictures -- all about flying leather- necks and submarine patrols and  frogmen and guerillas in the  Philippines. I don't want to take  anything away from those guys, but  what gets me is that there never was  a movie about P.O.W.s -- about  prisoners of war. Now my name is  Clarence Harvey Cook, -- they call  me Cookie. I was shot down over  Magdeburg, Germany back in 43. That's  why I stammer a little once in a  while, especially when I get excited  and I always get excited when I talk  about Stalag 17. I spent two and a  half years in Stalag 17. Stalag is  the Kraut word for prison camp and  number 17 was somewhere near Krems  on the Danube. There were about forty  thousand P.O.W.s there, if...

In the foreground the big gate. Above it a sign: STALAG 1 D. On both sides of the gate German guards in heavy coats rifles slung over their shoulders. They stomp about in  enormous boots with high cork soles to keep warm. Beyond gate about eight low barracks form a U about the Appell- ground. They are primitive one-story wooden structures al set up on stilts about two feet high. From one of the  buildings -- the Administration Building -- flies the  swastika. In between the barracks are the wash latrines. road runs through the slushy compound to the compound bey
A couple of German guards up there, one at the machine gu the other working the searchlight.

you bothered to count the Russians  and the Poles and the Czechs. In our  Compound there were about six hundred  and thirty of us -- all American  airmen, all shot down by the Krauts --  radio operators, gunners and engineers --  all sergeants. Now you put six hundred  and thirty sergeants together and  boinnnnng! -- you've got yourself a  situation! There was more fireworks  shooting off around that place! Take  for instance the story about the spy  we had in our barrack. It was about  a week before Christmas in '44 and  two of our guys -- Manfredi and  Johnson to be exact -- were just  getting set to blow the joint...
A German guard plodding along inside the barbed wire with four mean mastiffs straining at the leash. The light from the goon tower grazes over him.
The light sweeps slowly over the long shack. Catches the  sign: BARACKE 4. Catches one of the doors, locked from ou with a heavy wooden bar.

Bunks on both sides. Tripledecked bunks. In the bunks sev five American P.O.W.s huddled in blankets. In between the bunks, in the little space left to them, crude tables, an iron stove, makeshift stools. Every inch crowded with wha they have. Up above and all the way down the barrack hang their wash. Over all of it, the heavy stench of seventy-f men cooped up. From outside through the broken, patched  windows the searchlight sweeps over the bunks. The men ar all asleep. Or are they?

head_text.subj: THE FAR END OF THE BARRACK

text: This is the strategic spot of the story. In the five tier of bunks live our major characters. In the upper bunk lies HOFFY. Little fellow. Plenty of  authority. The Barrack Chief. His eyes are wide open. He studying his wristwatch, the phosphorescent numerals shin in the dark. In the other bunks lie the others, wide awake, tense: DUKE, big bellyacher. TRIZ, six-foot-three, ninety-eight pounds. PRICE, the barrack Security Chief. Quiet, touch of class. MANFREDI, no cover, fully dressed. HARRY, bug-eyed, cocky. BLONDIE, fair-skinned, boyish. JOHNSON, fully dressed like Manfredi. Scared. SEFTON, casual. In his mouth a cold cigar butt. Hoffy again. Still staring at the wristwatch. This is the moment. He lifts the metal dogtags off his chest and jigg them. This is the signal. Duke instantly slides out of the bunk, grabs up his blank and moves toward the window. A searchlight beam sweeps ac Duke goes flush on the ground. The light passes on. Duke  gets up again and starts hanging the blanket over the win Now the others go into action, silently, efficiently. Exc for Manfredi and Johnson they are all in long winter  underwear, some in slacks and socks. As for Sefton, he is lying in his bunk just watching them Blondie hangs a blanket over the window. Triz swings one  over the clothesline to shield off their end of the barra Hoffy and Price light a couple of handmade lamps: margari in tin cans with the wick stuck inside. Manfredi and Johnson are putting on their leather jackets Harry tries to awaken STOSH in the bunk above him. The wo boards around Stosh's bunk are plastered with Betty Grabl cheesecake. Harry pokes him. Stosh does not respond. Harr interlocks his fingers, puts them close to Stosh's ears a cracks them in a SHARP SALVO. Stosh opens his eyes, dazed Harry pats Stosh's cheek.
(in a whisper) Get up, Animal! Betty Grable's on  the phone!

Stosh gives him a dirty look. Gets out of the bunk. He an Harry move to the little iron stove. Triz is already  dismantling the pipe above the stove. Harry and Stosh lif the stove and start inching it to one side. Hoffy moving to a large bucket of water. It is a trick jo a bucket within a bucket. He lifts out the shallow inner  part with the water. Hidden underneath are some civilian  clothes. He takes them out, crosses to Manfredi and Johns (All the dialogue in this scene in whispers, of course.)
Here's your civilian clothes, boys.
Okay, Hoffy.
Duke takes the clothes from Hoffy and starts stuffing the into a small barrack bag.
Bury your Army outfits before you  get out of the forest.
Okay.
The compass is the top button on  your pants, Johnson.
Okay.

Sefton, propped up in his bunk, watches the proceedings w a pitying little smile. He eyes wander to Harry and Stosh By now they have moved the stove some four feet to the si and start carefully lifting some sawed-off planks out of floor. Blondie is standing watch by the blanket-covered window,  peeking out. Price slips a wire hook down into the crack between a bun and the wall, fishes out a sheaf of papers and walks to  Manfredi and Johnson.
Anybody asks for your papers, you're  French laborers.
He hands them the papers.
Your map -- your Kraut money -- Swiss  francs.
Roger.
Now, let's hear it once more, boys.
We've been over it a hundred times.
Let's hear it again.
We stick to the forest going west  until we hit the Danube --
Check.
Then follow the Danube up to Linz --
Check.
In Linz we hop a barge and go all  the way to Ulm --
From OFF come the WEIRD SOUNDS of an ocarina being played They turn. It's JOEY in his bunk playing the sweet potato. He's nuts all right.
Stop it, Joey -- go to sleep!
Joey hides the ocarina behind his back, afraid they may t it away.
(to Johnson) Go on. You're in Ulm.
Once in Ulm we lie low until night,  then take a train to Friedrichshafen.
Then once in Friedrichshafen we steal  a rowboat, get some fishing tackle,  and start drifting across the lake --  always south -- until we hit the  other side -- Switzerland.
Sefton has gotten out of his bunk, and is picking up the  margarine lamp.
Bingo. Once in Switzerland, just  give out with a big yodel so we'll  know you're there. It's a breeze,  boys.
He lights his cigar butt with the margarine lamp. Manfred and Johnson shoot him a nervous glance.
Stay out of it, Sefton.
Just one question. Did you calculate  the risk?
Harry and Stosh have by now removed the loose planks off floor. A small black hole gapes below them.
Ready.
Hoffy, Price, Manfredi and Johnson move toward the trap d Johnson carrying the barrack bag. Hoffy looks at his watc
You got ten minutes to get through  the tunnel. That'll bring you out  just when the Jerries are changing  shifts. (Turns to window) Blondie?
Blondie gives him the high sign.
(to Manfredi and  Johnson) Okay, boys -- peel off.
There are handshakes, goodbyes and good-lucks.
When you get going on those broads,  think of me!
Animal! Animal! Aren't you ashamed  of yourself? A couple of guys are  trying to escape and you're thinking  of broads. Broads?
He does a take.
(with feeling) We'll miss you, you cruds.
He turns and climbs down through the trap. Before Manfred follows him, he turns away, goes down on his knee, crosse himself quickly.
Johnson has already landed on the ground. Manfredi slips  down. They look around and start crawling off in the dire of the latrine.
Stosh is peering after them, his head hanging down throug the trap from above. Beyond him in the barrack, Hoffy, Pr and Duke bend over Stosh, waiting for developments.

From Stosh's point of view: Manfredi and Johnson have now reached the end of the barrack and are crawling into the  compound towards the wash latrine some fifteen feet away. searchlight sweeps dangerously towards them.

Stosh pulls up from the trap, his eyes closed, his finger in his ears. He doesn't want to see or hear the two out t get shot. The others stand petrified. No shots, no scream So Stosh bends down into the trap again.

Manfredi and Johnson just manage to fling themselves back under the barrack as the searchlight sweeps past. Then, t get on their feet again and dash to the wash latrine -- j ahead of another searchlight from the other direction.

A primitive, roofless structure, with wooden partitions  shielding it from the outside. Above, a water tank with p running down to spigots over a trough. Under the trough, wooden lattice to stand on. Manfredi and Johnson have reached first base. They stand  breathless. Then Manfredi picks up the lattice, leans it  against the trough, and lifts a dirt-covered trap leading into the tunnel. Johnson has tied the barrack bag to his ankle. They HEAR BARKING. Freeze.
Leading the mastiffs past the wash latrine. One of the  mastiffs is BARKING. He seems to smell something, but the other dogs pull him along.

Manfredi and Johnson wait until the BARKING fades in the  distance. Johnson, the barrack bag tied to his ankle, jum down into the narrow vertical shaft. Manfredi follows. He pulls the trap shut over his head in such a way that the  lattice falls into place on top of it.

A shaft about three feet square and five feet deep leads  into a narrow, crudely shored-up tunnel. Johnson and Manf light their Zippo lighters and start worming their way th the tunnel, Johnson leading the way, the barrack bag drag from his ankle.
Harry and Stosh moving the stove back into place. Hoffy f up the trick bucket. Price pacing up and down. Sefton lea against a bunk, smoking the cigar.
They ought to be under the barbed  wire soon.
(still covering the  window) Looks good outside.
I hope they hit the Danube before  dawn.
They got a good chance. This is the  longest night of the year.
I bet you they make it to  Friedrichshafen all right.
I bet they get all the way to  Switzerland!
And I bet they don't even get out of  the forest.
They all look at him.
Now what kind of a crack is that?
No crack. Two packs of cigarettes  say they don't get out of the forest.
That's enough, Sefton. Crawl back  into your sack.
He'd make book on his own mother  getting hit by a truck!
Sefton takes two packs of cigarettes from his pocket and  throws them on the table.
Anybody call?
Go on, Sefton -- butt out!
Wait a minute, Hoffy -- I want to  back those kids. I'll cover ten of  that.
He starts shaking cigarettes out of his pack onto the tab
I'll take five.
Eight.
Put me down for ten, you louse.
(throwing two packs  on the table) I'll call the whole pot.
Whatever you say. (calling off) Hey, Cookie -- get me some more  cigarettes.

COOKIE, a chipmunk of a kid, scrambles down from his bunk the one above Sefton's. Drags out a footlocker from under Sefton's bunk. The footlocker is chained to the bunk-post Cookie opens it, starts taking cigarettes out. About twelve guys are around Sefton by now, making their  bets.
Here's two and a half.
No butts.
Cookie comes over with a carton.
(With a stammer) W-w-will that do or do you want some  m-m-m --?
That'll do.
He rips open the carton.
Speak up, boys. Any more sports in  the crowd?

Johnson and Manfredi crawling on, by the light of their  Zippos. Johnson dragging the bag behind him. They are dri with perspiration. From above comes a little shower of lo earth. Johnson stops as he comes to the end of the tunnel. There another shaft leading up. He picks up a rusty can and sta digging at the earth above.

In the pine forest some thirty feet outside the barbed wi From the goon towers, the lights sweep over the camp and  over the edge of the forest. The tin can thrusts through the ground as Johnson digs in the open. Then, when the opening is wide enough, he climb out, his face covered with sweat and dirt. He helps Manfr out. They lie on the ground for a moment, exhausted. Then Johnson starts untieing the bag from his ankle.
Let's go.

He rises. There is a SHARP BURST of MACHINE GUN FIRE. Man falls instantly. Johnson, not knowing where the gunfire i coming from, tries to turn and run, the bag dragging behi him. From a hillock about thirty feet off a MACHINE GUN, manne by three German guards, is blasting away. A light from one of the goon towers picks up Johnson, run The machine gun gets him, ripping his chest. He spins and crumples to the ground. The light swings to Manfredi.  Bleeding, he tries to crawl back to the safety of the tun There is another BURST of FIRE --

The men have all run to the window and look out. All except Sefton and Cookie. They stand at the table whe the cigarettes are. And in back of them: Joey, sitting in his bunk, comprehending nothing. There is another BURST of FIRE. Then all is silent. The m turn back into the room, sickened.
Filthy Krauts!
What slipped up, Hoffy?
Don't ask me. Price was elected  Security.
(To Price) Okay, Security -- what happened?
I wish I knew. We had everything  figured out. To the last detail.
Maybe the Krauts knew about that  tunnel all the time!
Shut up, Animal!
Maybe they were layin' for 'em out  there!
(casually) Yeah. Maybe.
He gives Cookie a sign. Cookie pulls the front of his shi out of his pants and holds it out against the edge of the table. Sefton sweeps the mass of cigarettes into Cookie's shirt.
Hold it, Sefton. So we heard some  shots -- so who says they didn't get  away?
Anybody here wanna double their bet?

No answer. He nods to Cookie again. Cookie carries the  cigarettes to their bunks. Sefton follows him, kicks open the footlocker. Cookie dumps the loot in. The men are looking at them. Stosh sees a cigarette on th floor which Cookie has dropped. He picks it up and tosses into Sefton's footlocker viciously.

Another miserable day has begun. The barracks loom in the murky light. From the Administration Building -- the one with the swas come a dozen German guards, Lugers hanging from their bel They spread out and cross the muddy compound toward the  barracks, BLOWING WHISTLES shrilly. They lift the wooden  bars off the doors and go inside. FELDWEBEL SCHULZ has arrived at Barrack 4. He is an enorm man, about fifty-five. His cauliflower ears make a good  vegetable for his pig-knuckle face. He removes the bar, o the door, stands there WHISTLING like a madman, enters.

Funny thing about those Krauts. They  hated the sight of us yet they  couldn't wait to look at us again.  Every morning -- at six on the dot --  they'd have the Appell -- that's  roll call to you. Each barrack had  its own alarm clock. Our alarm clock  was Johann Sebastian Schulz. I  understand the Krauts had a composer  way back with the Johann Sebastian  in it -- but I can tell you one thing:  Schulz was no composer. He was a  Schweinehund. Oh, Mother -- was he  ever a lousy Schweinehund!
Schulz is marching down the barrack, beating the bunks wi his stick.
Aufstehen, gentlemen! Appell! Raus!  Hurry up!
Men start sliding out of their bunks. Others roll over in their sacks, groaning.
You must get up for roll call! Raus,  raus, gentlemen! Everybody aufstehen!  Raus!

We heard you, Schulz! And good morning to you! Aw, break it off! Why don't you take that whistle and  shove it! Tell the Kommandant I've got  dysentery!  Shut up, Schulz -- you're talking to  sergeants of the United States Air  Force!  Look at this chilblain. Ain't it a  beaut!
Raus! Raus! Aufstehen!
Whacking the bunks, Schulz has reached our end of barrack Hoffy and Price are getting into their clothes.
Come on, sack rats -- cut the bitchin'  and get up!
Duke, Triz and Blondie start climbing out, yawning and  scratching themselves.
Say, Schulz -- you guys had machine  gun practice last night?
(throwing up his hands) Ach, terrible! Such foolish boys.  Such nice boys. I'd better not talk  about it. It makes me sick to my  stomach.
You killed them, huh? Both of them?
Such nice boys! It makes me sick to --
Don't wear it out!
Schulz moves to Joey. Joey is sitting in his bunk, TOOTLI on his ocarina. Schulz raps the sweet potato with his sti
Outside! You, too! Put away the  piccolo!
Joey hides the sweet potato, staring at Schulz, frightene Schulz jerks him off the bunk.
Los, los. Dummkopf!
(pushing in) Lay off, Schulz. He's got a sickness.  He's krank.
Sometimes I think he is fooling us  with that crazy business.
Yeah? How would you like to see the  guts of nine pals splattered all  over your plane? (to Joey) C'mon Joey -- don't be afraid.
He helps him up and starts putting clothes on him. Schultz has approached bunk with Harry and Stosh. He poke Harry with the stick.
Aufstehen, gentlemen! Please! You do  not want to stay in bed on such a  beautiful morning we are having today!
Say, Schulz --
Jawohl?
Sprechen Sie deutsch?
Jawohl.
Then droppen Sie dead!
(splitting his sides) Ja -- ja! Droppen Sie dead! Always  mit the jokes! Droppen Sie dead!
He pokes Stosh with the stick.
Aufstehen! Appell!
He moves on. Harry bends over Stosh, shaking him.
Get up, Animal. Come on!
Stosh doesn't budge. Harry again gives him a knuckle-crac salvo. Stosh opens his eyes automatically.
(sweetly) Good morning, Animal! What'll it be  for breakfast? Scrambled eggs with  little sausages? Bacon and eggs sunny- side up? Griddle cakes? A waffle?
Stop it, Harry!
Coffee? Milk? Or how about a little  cocoa?
(grabbing him by the  collar) Why do you do this to me every  morning?
(with sadistic speed) Hamburger and onions! Strawberry  shortcake! Gefillte fish! Banana  split! French fried potatoes! Chicken  a la king!
The last items are coming out with a gurgling SOUND as St tightens the grip on Harry's neck.
I'll kill you, Harry -- so help me!
Let go, Animal! It's roll call! Hitler  wants to see you!
Sefton is standing near his bunk, getting dressed. Cookie helping him to zip up his luxurious flyer's boots.
Good morning, Sefton.
Good morning, Schulz. And how's Mrs.  Schulz? And all the little Schulzes?
Fine -- fine!
He looks at the two bunks which were occupied by Manfredi and Johnson. Takes off his gloves.
Let us see. We have now two empty  bunks here. (takes out pencil and  notebook, writes) Nummer einundsiebzig und Nummer  dreiundsiebzig in Baracke vier.
Suppose you let those mattresses  cool off a little -- just out of  decency?
Ja, ja, gewiss! It is only that we  are cramped for space with new  prisoners every day. (to the whole barrack) Gentlemen! Outside! Please! Do you  want me to have trouble with the  Kommandant again!
He starts herding them out the door.
Hey, Schulz -- as long as you're  going to move somebody in -- how  about a couple of those Russian  broads?
Russian women prisoners?
Jawohl!
Some are not bad at all.
Just get us a couple with big  Glockenspiels.
Ja! Ja! Droppen Sie dead!
Splitting his sides, he pushes them out, and follows.

Most of the P.O.W.s are out of their barracks by now. A m of freezing, disheveled men. Some wear Army coats over th underwear, knitted caps pulled down over their ears. Some are huddled in blankets, their feet in wooden clogs. Only few are fully dressed and shaven. A few are on crutches o bandaged up. They assemble before their respective barracks, forming a facing the center of the compound. The barrack chiefs are assisting the guards in lining them up, fifteen abreast a five deep. Supervised by Schulz and Hoffy the last ones from Barrack emerge.
All right, men -- fall in!
From off comes:
Ach-tung! Abzaehlen!

The HUB-BUB dies down. The guards march down the front line of their barrack gro counting the lines of five in German. As Schulz passes him, Blondie spots something in the midd of the compound. He nudges Duke. Duke nudges Price, Price Harry, Harry Stosh, Stosh Cookie. Cookie nudges Sefton wh is putting on his wool gloves. The glove drops. They all  look off in the same direction. In the center of the compound, right smack in the mud, li the corpses of Johnson and Manfredi, covered with a blank You know it's them because Johnson's foot is sticking out with the barrack bag still tied to it. A stir goes through the men of Barrack 4. They are hit ha All but Sefton. He looks at the corpses for a moment, the bends down, picks up the glove and starts putting it on. In front of the Administration Building a German Lieutena has been supervising a couple of guards as they lay narro planks over the mud in a line leading to the middle of th compound. He turns now to the P.O.W.s.
Parade Atten-tion!

The German guards come to rigid attention. The Americans  just stand there, sullenly. The Lieutenant comes to a heil salute. Through the open d of the Administration Building steps the Kommandant, OBER VON SCHERBACH, followed by another Lieutenant. Von Scherb is a big erect officer of the Potsdam School. Over his  shoulder hangs a furlined officer's coat. His boots shine like polished glass. He glances over the compound, then w down the planks, followed by the two Lieutenants, marchin through the mud on both sides of him. Von Scherbach stops the end of the plank. In front of him lies a deep puddle. clicks his heels and raises his hand in a heil salute.
Guten Morgen, Sergeants!
A glowering silence from the men. Von Scherbach lowers hi hand.

Nasty weather we're having, eh? And  I so much hoped that we could give  you a white Christmas -- just like  the ones you used to know... Aren't  those the words that clever little  man wrote -- you know the one who  stole his name from our capital --  that something-or-other Berlin?
He waits until his nasty little joke sinks in. Schulz has come up to the Lieutenant, salutes and hands him the slip of paper with the prisoner count.
Look at that mud. Come spring -- and  I do hope you'll still be with us  next spring -- we shall plant some  grass here -- and perhaps some  daffodils --
He turns to the Lieutenant for the tabulations.
Ich bitte!
(checking the papers) Melde gehorchsamst: 628 Gefangene.  Zwei Mann fehlen in Baracke vier.

(to the P.O.W.s) I understand we are minus two men  this morning. I am surprised at you,  gentlemen. Here I am trying to be  your friend and you do these  embarrassing things to me. Don't you  know this could get me into hot water  with the High Command? They do not  like men escaping from Stalag 17 -  especially, not enemy airmen from  Compound D. We plucked you out of  the skies and now we must see to it  you do not fly away. Because you  would come back and blast our cities  again. The High Command would be  very angry with me. They would strip  me of my rank. They would courtmartial  me, after all these years of a perfect  record! Now you wouldn't want that  to happen to me, would you?  Fortunately, those two men --

From the ranks of the men comes the EERIE DISSONANT SOUND of Joey's SWEET POTATO. Joey, in the second row of the Barrack 4 company, is play on his ocarina, oblivious to what is going on. Stosh turn and quickly grabs the ocarina from Joey's mouth. Von Scherbach chooses to disregard the little musical  interlude.

As I was saying: fortunately those  two men did not get very far. They  had the good sense to rejoin us again,  so my record would stand unblemished.  Nobody has ever escaped from Stalag  17. Not alive, anyway.

He snaps his fingers in the direction of the guard who st watch over the corpses. The guard pulls back the blanket in such a manner that al we can see is the barrack bag tied to Johnson's leg. The P.O.W.s however see the corpses. There is an ANGRY BU Hoffy marches up to Von Scherbach.
(saluting) Sergeant Hoffman from Barrack 4.
Yes, Sergeant Hoffman?
As the duly elected Compound Chief,  I protest the way these bodies are  left lying in the mud.
Anything else?
Yes. According to the Geneva  Convention, dead prisoners are to be  given a decent burial.

Of course. I'm aware of the Geneva  Convention. They will be given the  burial they deserve. Or perhaps you  would suggest we haul in twenty-one  cannons from the Eastern Front and  give them a twenty-one gun salute?
Hoffy turns on his heel and walks back to his men. Von Scherbach, without even looking at the corpses, snaps his fingers. The guard throws the blanket back over the  bodies.

For the last time, gentlemen, let me  remind you: any prisoners found  outside the barracks after lights  out will be shot on sight.  Furthermore, the iron stove in Barrack  4, the one camouflaging the trap  door, will be removed. And so that  the men from this barrack will not  suffer from the cold, they will keep  warm by filling in the escape tunnel.  Is that clear?
The men just stand there, in frustrated anger. Stosh clen the ocarina in his first.

All right, then, gentlemen. We are  all friends again. And with Christmas  coming on, I have a special treat  for you. I'll have you all deloused  for the holidays. And I'll have a  little tree for every barrack. You  will like that.
Stosh, with a quick underhand flip, throws the sweet pota in the direction of Von Scherbach. It lands smack in the middle of the puddle in front of Vo Scherbach and splashes his boots with mud.
(stiffening) Who did this?
Absolute silence.
I will give the funny man exactly  five seconds to step forward.
He looks about the compound. Five seconds pass. Nobody mo
Then you shall all stand here if it  takes all day and all night.
From the ranks of the men of Barrack 4, Stosh steps forwa
That is better!

But his triumph is short-lived, for almost instantly Harr steps forward alongside Stosh. Then Duke and Blondie and  Cookie. Spontaneously, men from all the other barracks fo until all the P.O.W.s have moved forward one step.
I see! Six hundred funny men! ...There  will be no Christmas trees! But there  will be delousing. (to Schulz) With ice water from the hoses!
He wheels about and marches back up the plank and into th Administration Building. His Lieutenants after him. Two o the guards start picking up the planks again.
(shouting, to the  P.O.W.s) Dismissed!

The men break ranks, going off in all directions, some ba to the barracks, some toward the latrines. Only Joey stands where he stood, his eyes fastened on the puddle. Slowly he walks toward it. He bends down and fish out his sweet potato, dripping with mud. It is broken. He wipes the pieces off on his coat and hides them inside hi jacket.

Packed with men from Barrack 4, about two dozen of them.  Others waiting outside for their turn. At the trough wash Hoffy, Price, Duke, Stosh, Harry, Cookie and Sefton. No s A couple of worn-out towels. Except for Sefton: He's got  soap, towel and tooth brush.
(imitating von  Scherbach) 'We will remove the iron stove --  the one that was camouflaging the  trap door.'
I'm telling you, Animal, these Nazis  ain't Kosher.
You can say that again!
I'm telling you, Animal -- these  Nazis ain't Ko --
(grabbing him) I said say it again. I didn't say  repeat it.
Triz reaches for Sefton's soap, but gets a sharp rap on t knuckles.
Private property, bub.
How come the Krauts knew about that  stove, Security? And the tunnel? How  come you can't lay down a belch around  here without them knowing it?
Look -- if you don't like the way  I'm handling this job --
Kill it, Duke. It's got us all  spinning.
I just want to know what makes those  Krauts so smart.
Maybe they're doin' it with radar.  Maybe they got a mike hidden some  place.
Yeah. Right up Joey's ocarina.
Or maybe it's not that they're so  smart. Maybe it's that we're so  stupid. Maybe there's somebody in  our barracks that's tipping 'em off!  One of us!
Come again?
You betcha. I said one of us is a  stoolie. A dirty, stinkin' stoolie!
Is that Einstein's theory? Or did  you figure it out yourself?
A P.O.W. sticks his head into the doorway.
(breathless) New dames in the Russian compound!
Stosh lets go with a SCREAM. He takes off like shot from cannon, Harry after him. Instantly the wash latrine is em of the men, wet as they are. Nobody is left but Price, Ho Duke, Sefton and Cookie.

It's a stampede. P.O.W.s are rushing across the compound  toward the Russian compound. Stosh, charging like a bull, gets tripped and falls flat his puss right into a mud puddle. Harry zooms past him. S picks himself up and runs after him, his winter underwear dripping with mud.

dividing the American and Russian compounds. P.O.W.s rush from all sides, about a hundred of them. They go as far a they are permitted; to a low warning wire, running parall to the big fence some fifteen feet away. To cross the war wire is verboten. The German guards up in the goon towers insure that. There is great excitement among the P.O.W.s. Some give ou with cat-calls and wolf-whistles; others just stand there staring. Beyond the fence a new batch of Russian prisoners has jus been brought in. German guards are counting some sixty  prisoners, about twenty of them women. They all are in  uniforms and wear boots, a bedraggled lot. The women are buxom dames, not exactly Golden Circle material, but this war. The Americans jump up and down trying to attract the wome attention. They throw cigarettes, chewing gum, chocolate. One guy is dancing the Kazatski, two of his pals holding up.
Yee-ow! Tovarich! Tovarich! Oh you sweethearts! Let's open the third front! Hey, Minks -- Pinsk! How about some borscht -- the two of  us!
Stosh and Harry push right up to trip wire. Stosh, plaste with mud, goes completely berserk.
Hey -- Russki -- Russki! Look at  those bublichkis! Over here!
Comrade! Comrade! Otchi Tchorniya --  Otchi Tchorniya!
Stosh puts two fingers in his mouth and tries to whistle. gets his mouth full of mud. Spits out the mud. Searches m through his pockets and throws whatever he can find acros the fence.
Chewing gum -- chewing gum!
Some of the Russian women break the ranks to pick up the  goodies that come flying over. The German guards push the back. The women smile at the Americans and wave.
(at the top of his  lungs) Look at me! I'm your baby! (to Harry) Get a load of that blonde one! Built  like a brick Kremlin!
Hey -- Comrade! Over here! This is  Harry Shapiro -- the Volga Boatman  of Barrack four!
Lay off! The blonde is mine!
The women are being led away by the guards.
(screaming) Hey, Olga -- Volga -- wait for me!
He takes off blindly toward the women, trips immediately  over the warning wire and falls flat on his face in the m again. Up in the goon tower the guard swivels the machine gun an yells down.
Zurueck oder wir schiessen! Zurueck!
Harry frantically grabs Stosh by the feet and pulls him b under the wire.
Let me go! Let me go!
They'll shoot you, Animal!
He lies right on top of him, holding him by the wrists.
I don't care! Let me go!
From OFF come the SOUNDS of a dishpan being beaten and sh of "Chow!" Some of the P.O.W.s start to go back to the  barracks.
It's chow, Animal! Chow!
Who wants to eat? I just wanna get  over there!
No you don't! You don't want any  broads with boots on!
I don't care if they wear galoshes!
You want Betty Grable!
Let me go!
(yelling) Betty Grable!
Stosh's face lights up.
Animal! When the war's over, remember  I told you I'd fix you up with Betty  Grable!
Yeah? How you going to fix me up  with Betty Grable?

How? We go to California. I got a  cousin that's working for the Los  Angeles Gas Company. That's how we  get the address, see? Isn't that  clever? I take you up to her house  and ring the doorbell and say,  'Congratulations, Miss Grable. We  have voted you the girl we'd most  like to be behind barbed wire with,  and I'm here to present the award'.
What's the award?
What d'ya think, jerko! You're the  award!
Me? What if she don't want me?
If she don't want you, she don't get  anything.
(grabbing him) You're teasing me again!
(gagging) Let go, Animal! It's chow! We'll  miss chow!
Stosh relaxes his hold and drops him like a limp rag. The scramble to their feet and run off towards Barrack 4.

Chow time. Most of the men sit around eating. Only a few still in line. They stand before a washtub, from which Tr ladles out a thin brew. Then each man gets a pitiful slic of sawdust bread, cut by Blondie at the table.
(in chow line) What's this stuff anyhow? Manicure  water?
This is what I like -- a hearty meal.
They finally found the formula: an  Ersatz of an Ersatz.
Hoffy, back in the line with Joey, carrying both chow can
What's holding up the parade?
Are you supposed to drink this stuff  or shave?
(next in line) Drink. (tastes the stuff) Shave.
Hoffy gets the two cans filled, gives one to Joey. This i the end of the line.
Anyone else want potato soup?
No answer. He takes out a homemade washboard and a pair o socks, puts them in the tea and starts scrubbing. Through the door, Stosh and Harry come running.
(out of breath) Chow! Where's the chow!
He dashes to his bunk, gets his chow can and is about to it into the tub, when he sees what Triz is doing.
Take your socks outa my breakfast!
Triz takes the socks out. Stosh dips in his chow can.
No, Animal.
No?
No. Your eyeball goes. The top of  your head. Gotta wind up with  athlete's stomach.

Stosh pours back his tea, a miserable man. His eyes fall the door. An electric shock goes through him. He grabs Ha arm. They look off: Sefton has come into the barrack and is crossing toward t iron stove. In his hand is the incredible -- more beautif than all the Kohinoors in the world: an egg. Harry and Stosh stand there with their eyes bulging. They start forward, drawn by the egg. Cookie is at the stove, tending a can of boiling water. H sees Sefton and puts a makeshift skillet (the banged-up t of a tin can) with a dab of margarine in it, on the fire. Sefton takes some keys out of his pocket, tosses them to  Cookie.
Set 'er up, Cookie. I'm starved.
Cookie goes towards Sefton's bunk. Sefton cracks the egg  into the skillet. Stosh and Harry move in, their eyes bul at sight of the sizzling beauty.
Easy, Animal! Easy!
Where'd that come from?
From a chicken, bug-wit.
A chicken?
Don't you remember, Animal? A chicken  lays those things.
It's beautiful! (to Sefton) You goin' to eat it all yourself?
Uh-huh. The yellow and the white.

He flips the egg over in the skillet. Harry and Stosh cov their eyes and yelp in panic. To their relief they see th the egg has landed safely. The aroma of the frying egg ha brought about six P.O.W.s down from their bunks. They cro around, their mouths watering.
Is it all right if we smell it?
Just don't drool on it.
You're not going to eat the eggshells?
Help yourself.
He tosses him the eggshells. Harry gives one half to Stos
(grateful) Thanks. You're a real pal! (on second thought) What're we goin' to do with it?
Plant it, Animal, and grow us a  chicken for Christmas.

Cookie, at Sefton's bunk, has taken from one of the  footlockers three cans, a china cup with a broken handle, fork, a spoon, and a salt-and-pepper shaker. He slams the locker shut with his foot and sets everything up on the o footlocker. Hoffy, Duke and Price, seated at the table ea chow, eye him with disgust. From the stove comes Sefton carrying the skillet and the of boiling water. The other P.O.W.s, including Harry and  Stosh, follow him, hypnotized by the egg. Sefton walks to his bunk, sits down on a little stool, puts salt and pepp on the egg. Cookie meanwhile has opened the cans. From on of them he measures out a spoonful of instant coffee into the cup and pours the boiling water over it. Sefton takes two lumps of sugar out of the other can and some Zwieback from the third can. The guys around him sniff the royal  breakfast. The situation is tense.
If I were you, Sefton, I'd eat that  egg some place else. Like for instance  under the barrack.
(sipping the coffee,  to Cookie) A little weak today.
Cookie puts another half a spoonful of instant coffee int the cup.
Come on, Trader Horn! Let's hear it:  what'd you give the Krauts for that  egg?
(eating away) Forty-five cigarettes. The price has  gone up.
That wouldn't be the cigarettes you  took us for last night?
What was I going to do with them? I  only smoke cigars.
Nice guy! The Krauts shoot Manfredi  and Johnson last night and today  he's out trading with them.
Look, this may be my last hot  breakfast on account of they're going  to take away that stove. So will you  let me eat it in peace?
Ain't that too bad! Tomorrow he'll  have to suck a raw egg!
He don't have to worry. He'll trade  the Krauts for a six-burner gas range.  Maybe a deep freeze too.
What's your beef, boys? So I'm  trading. Everybody here is trading.  Only maybe I trade a little sharper.  So that makes me a collaborator.
A lot sharper, Sefton! I'd like to  have some of that loot you got in  those footlockers!

You would, would you? Listen, Stupe --  the first week I was in this joint  somebody stole my Red Cross package,  my blanket and my left shoe. Well, I  wised up since. This ain't no  Salvation Army -- this is everybody  for himself. Dog eat dog.
You stink, Sefton!
He goes after him.
Come off it! Both of you!
A couple of P.O.W.s hold Duke back.
Now you've done it. You've given me  nervous indigestion. (he gets up) Anything else bothering you, boys?
Just one little thing. How come you  were so sure Manfredi and Johnson  wouldn't get out of the forest?
I wasn't so sure. I just liked the  odds.
He picks up the skillet with the half-eaten egg.
And what's that crack supposed to  mean?
They're lying dead in the mud out  there and I'm trying to find out how  come.
I'll tell you how come. (pointing at Hoffy) The Barrack Chief gave them the green  light. And you, our Security Officer,  said it'd be safe. That's how come.
He crosses to Joey who has been sitting on the edge of th bunk looking on blankly and puts the skillet with the egg his lap. Turns back to the others.

What're you guys trying to prove  anyway? Cutting trap doors! Digging  tunnels! You know what the chances  are to get out of here? And let's  say you do get all the way to  Switzerland! Or say to the States?  So what? They ship you to the Pacific  and slap you in another plane. And  you get shot down again and you wind  up in a Japanese prison camp. That's  if you're lucky! Well, I'm no escape  artist! You can be the heroes, the  boys with the fruit salad on your  chest. Me -- I'm staying put. And  I'm going to make myself as  comfortable as I can. And if it takes  a little trading with the enemy to  get me some food or a better mattress  or a woman -- that's okay by Sefton!
He strikes a match on the sleeve of Duke's leather jacket and lights himself a cigar.
Why you crud! This war's going to be  over some day -- then what do you  think we'll do to Kraut-kissers like  you?
He lunges forward and there is a fracas, the others tryin to hold them back. From off comes:
At ease! At ease!
MARKO, the Inter-barrack Communications officer, has ente from the compound, followed by a one-legged P.O.W., THE  CRUTCH. Marko gets up on a stool a piece of paper in his  hand.
(yelling) AT EASE!
Break it off, boys! At ease for the  news!
The ruckus subsides.
Today's Camp News! (reading) Father Murray announces that due to  local regulations the Christmas  midnight Mass will be held at seven  in the morning!
You can tell Father Murray to --

At ease! He also says, quote: All  you sack rats better show up for the  services and no bull from anybody.  Unquote. At ease! Monday afternoon a  sailboat race will be held at the  cesspool. See Oscar Rudolph of Barrack  7 if you want to enter a yacht. Next:  Jack Cushingham and Larry Blake will  play Frank deNotta and Mike Cohen  for the pinochle championship of the  camp.
That's a fix.
At ease! Tuesday afternoon at two  o'clock all men from Texas will meet  behind the north latrine.
Boos and cheers.

At ease! Next: A warning from  Kommandant von Scherbach. Anybody  found throwing rocks at low-flying  German aircraft will be thrown in  the boob. At ease! At ease! (then in a lower voice) Are the doors covered?
He looks around to make sure.
(to The Crutch) Okay, Steve. Give 'em the radio.

The Crutch, leaning against the edge of the table, pulls the empty pant leg. Attached there is a small radio, a  makeshift set with tubes showing. Also a pair of earphone Blondie starts getting it out.
(to Hoffy) You can keep it for two days.
Two days? We're supposed to have it  for a week!
You're lucky to get it at all. The  boys are afraid the Jerries'll find  it here. This barrack is jinxed.
Don't worry. We'll take care of it.
(to Stosh and Harry) Take some men and get the antenna  going. Let's see if we can catch the  BBC.
In the background, Harry gets a volley ball from under th bunk, Stosh picks up a roll of chicken wire from a corner the barrack, and the two lead six other P.O.W.s out into compound.
What about those guys last night?  What gives in this barrack anyway?
Just a little sickness. Somebody  around here's got the German measles.
He oughta know. He went to Johns  Hopkins. He used to be a bedpan.
What's the gag?
(imitating him) At ease! At ease!
Marko shrugs and turns to Hoffy.
Be sure to put down the news. Looks  like the Germans have started a  counter-offensive and the other  barracks want to know.
Marko and The Crutch go off.

The men are setting up the chicken wire, attaching one en to the barrack, and the other to a tall post: it becomes volley ball net, and in turn, an antenna. Stosh is slippi a wire through the window into the barrack. They divide i two teams, Stosh and Harry on opposite sides, and start  playing volley ball. In the background, Marko and The Cru are seen walking away.

Triz has connected the antenna wire to the radio on the t able. Blondie is sitting there with the earphones on, wor the dials, Price sitting next to him with pencil and pape The others stand around waiting.
Getting anything?
Getting too much. I'm tryin' to  unscramble.
If you can't get the BBC, how about  getting Guy Lombardo?
Are we boring you?
Hold it... Quiet...
He repeats what he hears over the earphones while Price w it down.

...has driven across Luxemburg...  The second German wedge is reported  fourteen miles west of Malmedy where  tank columns cut the road to  Bastogne... the Allied Air Force is  grounded by poor visibility...
The boys don't like what they hear.

The volley ball game is in fine progress, the ball poppin back and forth across the antenna. A German guard approac puzzled over the sports activity on this lousy winter day He is a singularly grim fellow. He starts circling them.  Harry and Stosh, to appear nonchalant, break into the  SCHNITZELBANK SONG. The guard moves dangerously close to window. Quickly Harry flips the ball over the net at him. The guard slaps it back across the net. Again Harry pops at him ... and slowly the guard finds himself sucked into the game.
Wunderbar! Isn't he wunderbar!
He's the grrrrreatest!
The guard permits himself a smile as he goes on playing.
The boys around the radio.

(Repeating what he  hears) ...five Panzer divisions and nine  infantry divisions of von Rundstedt's  army have poured into the wide  breach... meanwhile two of Patton's  tank units have been diverted toward  Bastogne and are trying to --
It's jammed again. Blondie fiddles with the dials.
Come on!
Static!
Static is right! The radio's static,  Patton's static, we're static!
Maybe it's going to be a longer war  than you figured -- eh, Duke?
Triz, who has been standing watch at the door, now sees:
Marching toward Barrack 4 are four German soldiers headed Schulz.

Triz reaches up and snaps a string. All the wash in the  barrack jumps up and down. That's the signal. Immediately the boys jump into action. Triz and Blondie  disconnect the wires. Hoffy takes the radio off the table and they all start dispersing.

Schulz and the four German soldiers are about to enter th barrack. Schulz pauses as he sees the guard playing volle ball enthusiastically. Schulz taps him on his back. The g wheels around, freezes, clicks his heels. Schulz gives hi disapproving look. Then he leads the four soldiers into t barrack. Harry, Stosh and the other P.O.W.s follow, worri Schulz and the soldiers enter the barrack, followed by Ha Stosh and the other players. The guys have just assumed innocent positions. A little t innocent maybe.
Did I interrupt something, gentlemen?
Yeah. We were just passing out guns.
(laughing) Always joking. Always making  wisecrackers!
Wisecrackers? Where did he pick up  his English? In a pretzel factory?

You always think I am a square. I  have been to America. (he shows them his  cauliflower ears) I wrestled in Milwaukee and St. Louis  and Cincinnati. And I will go back!  The way the war is going I will be  there before you!
You should live so long.
Schulz has taken a wallet out of his pocket, shows a  photograph to them.
This is me in Cincinnati.
Who's the other wrestler? The one  with the mustache?
That is my wife.
(taking the photograph) Look at all that meat. Isn't she the  bitter end!
(snatching it from  him) Give it back. You must not arouse  yourselves.

Hey, Schulz! I got a deal for you.  Suppose you help us escape. We'll go  home and have everything ready for  you in Madison Square Garden. For  the world championship! Schulz, the  Beast of Bavaria versus Halitosis  Jones!
Droppen Sie dead! (to the German soldiers) Raus mit dem Ofen. Los! Los!
The soldiers move toward the stove. As the scene proceeds they dismantle the stove and ultimately carry it out.
(to the P.O.W.s) All right, gentlemen! We will now  all go outside for a little gymnastic  and take some shovels and undig the  tunnel which you digged.
Why don't we just plug up that tunnel --  with the Kommandant on one end and  you on the other.
It is not me. It is the orders. I am  your friend. I am your best friend  here.
Cut out the guff, Schulz. We're on  to you. You know everything that's  happening in this barrack. Who's  tipping you off?
Tipping me off? I do not understand.
You're wasting your time, Duke. (to the others) Outside, everybody! Let's get it  over with.
Wait a second, Hoffy. Schulz says  he's our best friend. Maybe he can  give us a little hint.
Come on, Schulz! Spill it! How did  you get the information? About  Manfredi and Johnson? About the stove  and the tunnel? Who's giving it to  you? Which one of us is it?
Which one of you is what?
Which one of us is the informer?
You are trying to say that an American  would inform on other Americans?
That's the general idea. (looking at Sefton) Only it's not so general as far as  I'm concerned.
You are talking crazy!

(taking the cigar out  of his mouth) No use, Schulz. You might as well  come clean. Why don't you just tell  'em it's me. Because I'm really the  illegitimate son of Hitler. And after  the Germans win the war you'll make  me the Gauleiter of Zinzinnati.
You Americans! You are the craziest  people! That's why I like you! I  wish I could invite you all to my  house for a nice German Christmas!
(to Stosh) Why don't we accept, Animal? The  worst that can happen is we wind up  a couple of lamp shades.
(jovially) Raus! Raus! All of you!

By this time most of them have put on their warm clothes, caps and gloves and are filing out. Schulz starts to follow them, but stops short as he sees: The electric light bulb hanging by a wire from the ceilin Just the bulb. No shade. The wire is tied up into a slip  knot. Schulz reacts to what he has seen. he watches the last of the P.O.W.s leave, and the Germans carry the stove out of the barrack. He closes the door. His entire attitude has  changed. He is serious and efficient. He walks over to th chess set on the table. Out of his pocket he takes a ches piece -- a black queen -- and exchanges it with the black queen from the set. He puts it in his pocket. Steps over the light bulb, pulls the slip knot free and exits. The light bulb hangs straight now, swaying gently in the  empty barrack.

The men from Barrack 4 are lined up between the latrine a the barbed wire, starting to dig up the tunnel. They are  supervised by German guards. In the background, Schulz is crossing from the barrack towards the Administration Buil As the men dig, they look off at:

He was the Beast of Bavaria all right,  as we pieced it together later. And  there was a stoolie in our barrack,  just as Duke said. They had a very  simple communications system -- Schulz  and the stoolie...
An open German half-truck driving toward the big gate,  carrying two crude wooden coffins.

That's how the Krauts knew about the  tunnel, from the day we started  digging. Those poor suckers Manfredi  and Johnson! They got out of Stalag  17 sure enough, only not quite the  way they wanted to go.

The men have stopped digging. As the CAMERA goes down the row they take off their caps. Joey does not comprehend.  Blondie, standing next to him, takes the cap off for him. The CAMERA PULLS PAST Cookie who has taken his cap off, a now STOPS on Sefton. He has seen the coffins. He has seen the others take off their caps. He takes the cigar out of his mouth, snuffs it out, puts it into his pocket, and sl pulls off his cap.

As for the stoolie, I just wish he  had German measles because when you  get the measles you break out all  over in red spots, and we could have  pegged him easy. As it was it could  have been anybody in our outfit --  Duke or Hoffy or Price or Goofy Joey  or Harry or the Animal or maybe  Sefton. Sergeant J.J. Sefton. I guess  it's about time I told you a few  more things about that Sefton guy.  If I was anything of a writer I'd  send it in to the Reader's Digest  for one of those 'Most Unforgettable  Characters You've Ever Met'...

A circle about 15 feet in diameter is drawn on the barren ground with white lime. Around it, some forty G.I.s. In t center, Cookie, holding a cardboard box. To one side, sta on a wooden crate, Sefton. In front of him, a makeshift  bookie's desk, a heap of loose cigarettes on top. G.I.s a crowding around, making wagers in cigarettes. Hanging off one side of the desk, the odds board: NO. HORSE ODDS 1.  Whirlaway 3:1 2. Seabiscuit 5:1 3. Equipoise 1:1 4. Twent Grand 4:1 5. Schnickelfritz 10:1

...he was a B.T.O., Sefton was. A  Big Time Operator. Always hustling,  always scrounging. Take for instance  the horse races. Every Saturday and  Sunday he would put on horse races.  He was the sole owner and operator  of the Stalag 17 Turf Club. He was  the Presiding Steward, the Chief  Handicapper, the Starter, the Judge,  the Breeder and his own bookie. He  was the whole works, except that I  was the stable boy for ten smokes a  day.
Step up, boys! The horses are at the  post!
Five on Equipoise! Give me Equipoise -- ten on the nose! Two on Twenty Grand! Schnickelfritz for me. Five smackers! Equipoise -- one solid pack!
(an unkempt bum) Five on Seabiscuit! Pay you when the  Red Cross parcels come in.
No credit.
Have a heart, Sefton!
Sorry. It's against the rules of the  Racing Commission. (calling out) Already? Any more bets? Shake 'em  up, Cookie!
Cookie shakes the cardboard box, puts it face down on the ground in the center of the circle.
Let 'er go! They're off and running  at Stalag 17!

Cookie has lifted the box. There are five mice of various colors with numbers 1 to 5 attached to their backs. The m start spreading hesitantly in all directions. The P.O.W.s YELL and SCREAM, rooting for their horses to  reach the circle line first. Among the P.O.W.s Stosh and Harry. Stosh, with a bundle o mutuel tickets in his hand, screaming his head off.
Equipoise! Oh, you beauty! This way!  This way!
Equipoise, No. 3, pulls in front and is only a few feet f the edge of the circle.
Equipoise! Equipoise! What did I  tell you, Animal?
Come on, baby! Daddy's going to buy  you a hunk of cheese!
Equipoise, now only a foot from the finish line, suddenly stops and goes into a dizzy spin. The other mice gain rap
Straighten out, you dog! This way!  That's no horse -- that's a dervish!  Please! This way! Come to Daddy!
In a turmoil of SCREAMING G.I.s, Schnickelfritz passes  Equipoise, still spinning like a top, and crosses the lin
The winner is No. 5: Schnickelfritz!
Stosh grabs Harry.
Schnickelfritz! I told you  Schnickelfritz! Why'd you make me  bet on Equipoise!
I clocked him this morning. He was  running like a doll.
(choking him) You clocked him! Why don't I clock  you?
(calling out) The next race will be a claiming  race for four months old and upward  which have not won since November  17th.
While Sefton pays off the winners, Cookie puts up a new o board. New bettors start lining up on the other side. Amo them, Harry and Stosh.
It's a good thing nobody ever asked  for a saliva test. Because I wouldn't  have put it past Sefton to stiff a  horse once in a while -- especially  when the betting was heavy.

Near Sefton's bunk, the distillery is set up: a Rube Gold contraption of old tin cans and a maze of piping, a marga lamp burning under the boiler. The whole thing SPUTTERS a HISSES. Behind a makeshift wooden shelf -- the bar -- stands Cook pouring drinks for some eight customers, among them Harry and Stosh, crocked. In Stosh's hand is the big Betty Grab cheese-cake photo from his bunk.

Another one of his enterprises was  the distillery. Believe it or not,  he ran a bar right in our barrack,  selling Schnapps at two cigarettes a  shot. The boys called it the  Flamethrower, but it wasn't really  that bad. We brewed it out of old  potato peels and once in a while a  couple of strings off the Red Cross  parcels, to give it a little flavor.
(in a crying jag) It's not fair, Harry. I'm telling  you, it's not fair! She's been married  for over a year! My Betty! She had a  baby! Didn't you hear it on the radio!
C'mon, Animal! Pull yourself together! (off) Hey, Cookie! Belt us again!
He pushes their little condensed milk cans, serving as  jiggers, across the bar, counts out four cigarettes.
Look at her! Isn't she beautiful!  Married an orchestra leader!
So what? There's other women!
Not for me! Betty! Betty!
Cut it out. Animal! I'll fix you up  with a couple of those Russian women!
(sarcastically) You'll fix me up!
Sure, Animal! I'll get you over there!
How? Pinky Miller from Barrack 8  tried to get over there and they  shot him in the leg!
It takes a gimmick, Animal, and I  figured us a little gimmick.
You did?
(tapping his forehead) Sharp. Sometimes I'm so sharp it's  frightening.
Cookie slides over the two tin jiggers. Harry picks them hands one to Stosh.
(toasting) To the Brick Kremlin!
(his eyes on the  cheesecake photo) She'll never forgive me!
Bombs away!
They both drink it down in one gulp, Harry holding his no It's terrible stuff and hits them hard. Stosh goes into a violent fit of coughing, pulling his barrack cap down ove his eyes.
(to Cookie) What are you serving today? Nitric  acid?
I only work here. Talk to the  Management.
He points to Sefton, who is taking inventory of the cigar in his footlocker: cartons, packages, loose ones. He is  tabulating the amounts on a piece of paper.
All right, Management. What are you  trying to do? Embalm us while we're  alive?
Exactly what did you expect for two  cigarettes? Eight year old Bottled- In-Bond? All the house guarantees is  that you don't go blind. (to Cookie) Don't ever serve 'em again.
Blind! Harry! Harry!
He staggers around, not realizing his cap is pulled down  over his eyes.
Harry -- I'm blind!
(pushing up his cap) Blind? How stupid can you get, Animal?  I drank the stuff myself.
Suddenly he seems not to see too well himself. He gropes  around in panic.
Animal! Animal! Where are you, Animal?

A big telescope, about seven feet long, is set up on a tr at the window pointing toward the Russian Compound. The  telescope is made of various-sized cans soldered together It's run by Cookie, behind a table, piled with cigarettes and chocolate bars. Bent down peering through the telesco panning it slowly, is a P.O.W. Across the barrack stretch a long line of impatient customers, all the way to the op door and out of it. Cookie taps the peeker to indicate hi time is up. The next in line pays his cigarette and peeks

The killer-diller, of course -- the  real bonanza -- was when Sefton put  up the Observatory. He scrounged  himself some high-powered Kraut lenses  and a magnifying mirror and got Ronnie  Bigelow from Barrack 2 to put the  whole shebang together for a pound  of coffee. On a clear day you could  have seen the Swiss Alps, only who  wanted to see the Swiss Alps? It was  about a mile away, that Russian  delousing shack, but we were right  on top of it. It cost you a cigarette  or a half bar of chocolate a peek.  You couldn't catch much through that  steam, but believe you me, after two  years in that camp just the idea  what was behind that steam sure  spruced up your voltage.
About a dozen Russian women, wrapped only in blankets, wa in line. The telescope pans across a couple of windows. T are completely steamed-up by the disinfecting vapors.
The P.O.W. is glued to the telescope. Cookie taps him on shoulder.
Let's go! Thirty seconds to a  customer.

Without moving his eye from the telescope, the P.O.W. fis another cigarette from his pocket and gives it to Cookie. Sefton stands at the open barrack door, a cold cigar in h mouth. He surveys the landoffice business, both inside an out, for beyond him a line of about forty more P.O.W.s  stretches into the compound.
(from rear of line) Hey, Sefton -- what's snarling up  the traffic? By the time we get to  look they'll be old hags!
Simmer down, boys. There'll be a  second show when they put the next  batch through.
Hoffy, Price and Duke come in from the compound. Hoffy ca the situation and pulls Sefton to the side.
What's the big idea, Sefton? Take  that telescope out of here.
Says who?
Says me.
You take it out. Only you're going  to have a riot on your hands.
Every time the men get Red Cross  packages you have to think up an  angle to rob them.
When the Krauts find that gadget  they'll throw us all in the boob.
They know about that gadget. I'd  worry more about the radio.
I suppose they also know about your  distillery and the horseraces?
That's right.
Just what makes you and them Krauts  so buddy-buddy?
Ask Security. (to Price) You tell him, Price. You've got me  shadowed every minute of the day. Or  haven't you found out yet?
Not yet.
Answer the question. How do you rate  all those privileges?
I grease the Kraut guards. With ten  percent of the take.
And maybe a little something else?
A little something what?
He strikes a match on Duke's dogtag and lights his cigar.
(lunging at him) Maybe a little information!
Hoffy and Price hold back Duke.
Break it off!
How much more do we have to take  from him?
There'll be no vigilante stuff. Not  while I'm Barrack Chief.
From the window come excited shouts.
Hey, look at them!  It's Harry and the Animal!  Look what they're doing!
Everybody in the barrack is dashing toward the window giv out on the Russian Compound. Hoffy, Price, Duke, and Seft follow after. The window is packed by G.I.s staring out. More crowding
Those crazy jerks!  They won't get away with it!  The Krauts will shoot them!

This is Harry's little gimmick: He and Stosh are painting white line down the middle of the road leading towards th Russian Compound. Stosh carries the bucket and Harry, mov backwards, wields the brush. They are very close now to t barbed wire fence dividing the compounds. A bespectacled  German guard is standing in front of his sentinel house. They crouch as low as they can as they paint themselves  through the gate past the guard and up the road toward th Russian delousing shack. The guard gives them a glance. I looks okay to him. He starts stamping about at the open g
G.I.s at the window, watching in great excitement.
They're past the fifty yard line!  Quarterback sneak!  Look at them go!
(in chorus) We want a touchdown! We want a  touchdown! We want a touchdown!
Those idiots! They'll paint themselves  into their graves!
Harry and Stosh are doing dandy as they paint up the high Harry gets his bearings: the delousing shack is some twen five feet off the road. He paints a very elegant turn off the highway.
The German guard is stamping up and down. Suddenly he doe double take as he sees:
The white line leading down the middle of the highway vee off idiotically over the terrain towards the shack.
He stands there perplexed, then takes off after them.

Harry and Stosh have now painted up to the window of the  shack. Without even stopping, they paint right up the wal and around the window. As they paint, they peer in throug the thick steam (through which we cannot distinguish  anything). Now, they paint down the building on the other side of the window and toward the doorway. Into their pat come the boots of the German guard. They paint right over the boots. Then they see the butt of the guard's rifle. T look at each other. They are in trouble. They stop painti and straighten up slowly.
Was ist denn hier los? Sie sind  verhaftet!

Harry gives the guard's eye-glasses a couple of quick str of paint. Dropping paint and brush, Stosh and he run like mad back toward the gate. The guard stands there struggling with his glasses. The Russian women, huddled in blankets, giggle their head off.

About twenty P.O.W.s lazing about. The sack rats in their bunks. Triz and Price playing chess, Joey looking on blan Sefton, a towel around his neck, is sitting in a chair be shaved by Cookie. Stosh, in his bunk, is carving a new oc for Joey out of wood. CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY to: The electric light bulb, hanging straight and innocent on its wire.
Now let me see, what came next? Oh,  yes. Next came those new prisoners.  'Twas two days before Christmas when  all through the camp, not a creature  was stirring, not even that lamp.
At ease! At ease!
Marko, carrying a handful of letters and a book, has ente followed by The Crutch.
Mail call!
The whole barrack springs to life, everyone moving toward Marko with whistles, screams and hoorays. Joey, who keeps staring at the chess board. Sefton and Cookie go on with shave.

At ease! At ease! First, the  Kommandant is sending every barrack  a little Christmas present. A copy  of Mein Kampf. In the words of Oberst  von Scherbach: 'Now that a German  victory is in sight, all American  prisoners are to be indoctrinated  with the teachings of der Fuehrer.  Unquote. In my own words: (he lets go with a  belch) Unquote.
He tosses the book into the air. Duke catches it.
That's the wrong direction.
He flings it at Sefton. It sails past Sefton's head. Cookie ducks. Sefton doesn't even bat an eyelash.
You must have been some tail gunner! (to Cookie) Go ahead, Cookie.
Come on, let's get that mail. Anything  for Stanislaus Kuzawa?
At ease! At ease!
As Marko calls out the names he hands out the letters. So of the men open them immediately. Others go to their bunk to read.
Martin. Shapiro. Price. Trzcinski.  McKay. Shapiro. Shapiro. Manfredi.
There is an awkward pause, then Marko puts Manfredi's let in his pocket.
Shapiro. Musgrove. McKay. Peterson.  Cook.
Cookie comes up for his letter. So do Duke and Blondie. ( names are Musgrove and Peterson.)
Pirelli. Coleman. Agnew. Shapiro.
(in a little voice) Nothing for Kuzawa?
Shapiro. Shapiro.
(to Harry) Just what makes you so popular?
(fanning the letters) Frightening, isn't it? Fifty million  guys floating around back home and  all those dames want is Sugar-lips  Shapiro.
McKay, Agnew. Here, Stosh.
He holds out a letter.
(revitalized) Yeah?
Give this to Joey, will you?
Oh.
Marko has now distributed all the letters.
At ease! At ease! Here's a little  something from Father Murray. One to  each barrack.
He has knelt down in front of The Crutch and pulls out fr the empty pant's leg a little Christmas tree.
And he says he wants you cruds to  cut out all swearing during Yuletide.
How'd he get those trees?
I don't know. Prayed, I guess. They  grew out of his mattress.
Marko sticks the tree into one of the margarine cans.
What'll we use for decorations?
For that you got to pray yourself.
He goes, followed by The Crutch. Stosh sits next to Joey at the table, reading his letter him.

'...and we do hope that you will  finish that last year of law school  when you come back home...' (looks up at Joey) Law school?! You don't want to be a  stinking lawyer with a stinking brief  case in a stinking office, do you,  Joey?
Joey just sits there. Stosh goes on reading.
'...And do keep writing, son. Your  letters are very dear to us. With  all our love, Dad.' Here, Joey, take  it.
Joey doesn't move.
It's from your Dad, Joey.
He shoves the letter into Joey's pocket.

The next time we write to your folks,  Joey, you know what you're going to  say? You're going to say you don't  want to be a lawyer any more. You  want to be a musician -- like play  the flute, maybe -- eh, Joey?
There is a fleeting smile on Joey's face. Triz, in his bunk, a crumpled letter in his hand, is mumb to himself.
I believe it! I believe it!
You believe what?

My wife. (Reading) 'Darling, you won't believe it, but  I found the most adorable baby on  our doorstep and I have decided to  keep it for our own. Now, you won't  believe it, but it's got exactly my  eyes and nose...' Why does she always  say I won't believe it? I believe  it!
Blondie is reading his letter, several G.I.s around him,  among them Duke.

This is from my mother. (he reads) 'I saw a wonderful article on German  prison camps in one of the magazines.  They showed pictures of the tennis  courts and they also say that in the  winter they freeze them over so you  boys can ice skate...'
Anything about us grouse hunting in  the Vienna woods?
(continues to read) '...In a way I'm glad you're not in  America right now -- with everything  rationed here, like gas and meat.'
Heart-rendering, ain't it? Why don't  we send them some food parcels?
Harry is busy with all his mail. He has opened six of his letters and is now working on the last. Stosh comes into SHOT and peeks over his shoulder.
What do those broads say?
What do they always say?
That's what I wanna hear.
(hiding the letters) It's not good for you, Animal.
Stosh grabs one of the letters from him.
Hey! This is with a typewriter! It's  from a finance company!

So it is from the finance company.  So it's better than no letter at  all. So they want the third payment  on the Plymouth. (showing him five  more letters) So they want the fourth, the fifth,  the sixth and the seventh. So they  want the Plymouth.
Sugar-lips Shapiro! Frightening,  ain't it?

(holding up the last  letter) This is a good one! (mounts a stool) Shut up, everybody! Listen to this! (he reads) 'The President of the United States  to Harry Shapiro. Greeting: Having  submitted yourself to a local board,  you are hereby notified to report...'  What do you know! So now I'm a draft  evader!

Hoffy is walking across the muddy compound towards the  barrack, leading a couple of new prisoners: LIEUTENANT DU and SERGEANT BAGRADIAN. They are exhausted but, by contra to the old P.O.W.s, remarkably clean. They are followed b P.O.W., carrying two barrack bags.
(opening door to  barrack) This is it, gentlemen. Don't bother  to scrape your shoes.
He leads them into the barrack.
Hoffy leads in Dunbar, Bagradian and the P.O.W. with the  barrack bags. He snaps the line, the wash jiggles through the barrack. Everybody turns.
Okay, gang! Meet our new guests.  This is Lieutenant Dunbar and this  is Sergeant Bagradian.
Hi.
Lieutenant?!
The whole barracks comes to its feet and salutes him with mock reverence. Harry dashes up and polishes with his sle the Lieutenant's bar.
Knock it off, boys. The pleasure's  all mine.

The Lieutenant will be with us for a  week or so until the Krauts can ship  him to the officers' camp in Silesia.  Looks like all the railroad lines  out of Frankfurt are fouled up because  somebody blew up an ammunition train.
Somebody, my eye. (indicating Dunbar) The Lieutenant did it -- right in  the station -- with fifty German  guards around.
(climbing off the  stool) Well! Glad to have you with the  organization!
You're just in time for the Christmas  Pageant.
Looks more like the lost company of  Tobacco Road.
(indicating Bagradian) He's an actor. You should see him do  imitations. He can imitate anybody.
If he can imitate a girl, he's made.
Hey -- do Lionel Barrymore.
Do Grable.

Stop it, boys. They were shot down  two days ago and they've been on  their feet ever since. (to Stosh and Harry) Fix them some tea, will you? (to Dunbar and  Bagradian) Price will show you your bunks.
Price leads them towards the bunks which were formerly  occupied by Manfredi and Johnson, the P.O.W. with the bar bags following them.
We had a couple of unexpected  vacancies. Which one will it be --  the upper or lower, Lieutenant Dunbar?
Doesn't matter.
Cookie is just finished shaving Sefton. Sefton turns in h chair.
Lieutenant Dunbar? It wouldn't be  James Schuyler Dunbar? From Boston?
Yes, it would. Do we know each other?
(indicating Sefton) He's from Boston, too. But you  wouldn't know him, not unless you  had your house robbed.
Sefton gets up, wiping the soap off his ears with the tow

Maybe he would. We applied for  Officers' Training together, remember?  They turned me down, but I'm glad to  see you made it. Of course, it  couldn't be that all that dough behind  you had something to do with it! (to the others) His mother's got twenty million  dollars.
Twenty-five.
They've got a summer house in  Nantucket, with an upstairs polo  field. (to Price) You better put a canopy over his  bunk.
Lay off, Sefton.
(to Dunbar) With your mother's pull, how come  you're not a chicken colonel by now?
Lay off, I said -- if you don't want  your head handed to you.
(from the table) Tea is being served on the verandah!
Harry sets two chow cans on the table.
(to Stosh) Where are the napkins, Animal?
Stosh tears off two sheets of toilet paper from a roll,  separates them and puts them next to the chow cans. By no Dunbar and Bagradian come over to the table.
(to Dunbar, a la Ronald  Colman) Do be seated, Bonita. What a perfectly  charming table arrangement. They  must have copied it from House  Beautiful.
Stosh starts pouring hot water from the pot.
Animal! How many times have I told  you, you got to pour from the left!
Stosh reverses his direction. Harry has taken a faded tea bag out of his watch pocket. He dunks it three times into each chow can. Then, looking at the tea bag as if it were watch:
Dinner will be served at seven sharp.  Black tie.
He puts the tea bag back into his watch pocket.
Where'd they get you, Lieutenant?  Over Frankfurt?
On the Schweinfurt run.
How many ships did you lose?
Half the group.
Flying out of England?
Yes. Paddington, 92nd Bomber Group.
(wide-eyed) Hey, Lieutenant. How did you blow up  that train with fifty guards around?
Just lucky, I guess.

Don't let him kid you. Cagney couldn't  have pulled a sweeter job. (a la Cagney) All right, boys. We were waiting in  the depot in Frankfurt, see? And  there was an ammunition train coming  through, the longest ammunition train  you ever saw, see? So Dunbar gets  himself in the men's room, see? Fixes  himself a time bomb, busts open the  window and just as the train moves  out, lays the thing in there, see?  So then, he comes out like nothing's  happened and three minutes later you  can hear it -- boom! Broke every  window in Frankfurt. It was gorgeous!
I wouldn't talk about things like  that.
(himself again) They never caught on.
They may. That's why I would keep my  mouth shut.
We're all Americans here!
The Krauts have a way of getting  information.
Especially in this barrack.
How?
That's what we'd like to know.

Sefton is just putting on his leather jacket. He has been listening to what has been going on. Cookie hands him out the footlocker a bottle of Rhine wine and a carton of  cigarettes. Sefton tucks them inside his leather jacket.  Cookie now hands him a pair of silk stockings.
(in a low voice) There's only one pair left.
(putting the stockings  in his pocket) We'll get some more.
He puts his cap on and walks toward the door. As he passe the others:
Where does a guy take a hot shower  around here?
Hot showers? Dig him!
Sorry. No hot showers. You wash in  the latrine.
Latrine?
(stopping in his tracks) What did you expect, glamor boy? The  Officers' Club with a steam room and  a massage maybe?

(going after him) Just a minute. You made a couple of  cracks before and I let them slide.  But I don't intend to take any more.  If you resent my having money, start  a revolution, but get off my back.
Look, Lieutenant. All your dough  won't help you here. Because here  you're on your own. And no mother to  throw you a lifebelt. Now let's see  how good you can swim.
He has picked a little twig off the Christmas tree. He pu it in his buttonhole.
Sorry, boys, but my taxi's waiting.
He goes out.
What's wrong with him?
Plenty.
Number one on the rat parade!
Hoffy nods to Duke. Duke leaves the barrack, after Sefton

On the muddy compound there is a tag football game going with some forty G.I.s watching. Sefton is walking along. Behind him, Duke has come out of the barrack and is following him. Sefton becomes aware of it. Nonchalantly, he walks into a wash latrine.

Sefton comes in. There is another P.O.W. there, a colored guy, just finishing washing his hands. Sefton quickly cli up a couple of rungs of the ladder leading to the water t and stops there. The colored P.O.W. doesn't notice it.

Duke stands some distance away, watching the only pair of legs visible under the raised partition. The legs move no down the length of the latrine and out the other end. The colored P.O.W. emerges and walks off with his back toward Duke. Duke follows him.
Sefton jumps off the ladder and exits the way he came in.

It was a funny thing about Sefton  and me. I guess I knew him as well  as anybody else in the camp because  I had worked for him for two years.  But there were lots of things I didn't  know about him. Take for instance,  where he would disappear to once in  a while. Of course, I had a hunch,  but it seemed so crazy I couldn't  quite believe it -- Just as I would  never have believed that Sefton was  the guy that would give away  Lieutenant Dunbar for blowing up  that ammunition train.

Duke is still following the wrong guy. Now the P.O.W. sto to talk to a pal. Duke realizes his mistake. He dashes ba into the wash latrine and comes out again. He stands ther frustrated. With the football players rushing about, pass being thrown and G.I.s milling around, he has lost Sefton

START on the electric light -- the cord is again tied up  into a noose. CAMERA PANS to Harry. He is made up a la Hitler; his hair combed across his forehead and a charcoal mustache on his lip. He is now making up Joey as Hitler, with two fingers blackened in charcoal. Joey just sits in his bunk, dumbly At the table, Hoffy is playing gin with Dunbar. Price  kibitzing.
(to Harry) Cut the horseplay, Harry. What's the  matter with you guys?
And don't blame me if you all wind  up in the cooler.
How's two?
He lays down his hand. Stosh, at the door, holds it slightly ajar and peeks out  into the compound. He too is made up as Hitler.
Get ready! Here he comes!
He SLAMS the door, snaps wash line.
A German truck draws up, loaded with blankets. Schulz, si next to the driver, gets out and starts into the barrack. Two German guards stay behind.

Schulz enters, closes the door behind him. From OFF comes Bagradian's voice: A double-talk German gibberish in the  characteristic guttural sounds of der Fuehrer. Schulz stops, mystified. Bagradian stands on a stool giving a lecture to some thir P.O.W.s, all of them with their backs towards Schulz.  Bagradian's face cannot be seen as he holds the Mein Kamp book in front of it. Schulz listens for a little while to Bagradian's ranting and raving. Then he stamps his foot.
Gentlemen! Gentlemen! Attention!
Bagradian lowers the book. He too is made up as Hitler. H raises his arm in the Nazi salute.
Heil, Hitler!
(responding  automatically) Heil, Hitler!
He catches himself, lowers the arm.
(jovially) Droppen Sie dead.
(a la Hitler) Quiet! We are indoctrinating! (to the others) Is you all indoctrinated?
(in unison) Jawohl.
Is you all good Nazis?
Jawohl.
Is you all little Adolfs?
Jawohl!
Then we shall all zalute Feldwebel  von und zu Schulz! About face!
The P.O.W.s wheel around and face Schulz. They are all ma up as Hitler.
Sieg heil! Sieg heil! Sieg Heil!
After each 'Sieg heil' they raise their arms in salute.
Ach! One Fuehrer is enough! Now  please, gentlemen! Take off the  mustaches immediately. Or do you  want me arrested by the Gestapo?
Jawohl!
You would be very sorry to get a new  Feldwebel. Somebody without a sense  of humor.
Okay, boys. Wipe off the mustaches.  Now what is it, Schulz?
The men start wiping off the mustaches and straightening  their hair.

Gentlemen, tomorrow morning the Geneva  Man is coming to inspect the camp  whether we are living up to the  International Convention. I am sure  he will find we are treating you  very well. You must not run around  in your underwear. And take off the  wash. The Kommandant wants all the  barracks to be spic and also span.
We'll put pink ribbons on the bedbugs.
The Kommandant also sends you clean  blankets. He wants every man to have  a new, clean blanket.
We know! We got them last year. Five  minutes after the Geneva Man was  gone, the blankets were gone.
One more thing, gentlemen. The  Kommandant told me to pick up the  radio.
What radio?
The one you are hiding in the barrack,  don't you know? The one your friend  without the leg is smuggling all  over the compound.
Schulz, you're off your nut!
Give me the radio.
We have no radio.
All right, gentlemen, I will find it  myself. Now let's see.
He starts wandering around the barrack, drawing closer an closer to the trick bucket.
Am I cold? Am I getting warmer? Hot,  maybe? Very hot?
He has reached the bucket. With his boot he kicks it over the floor. The water spills on Cookie's shoes. The radio the earphones lie on the floor.
(picking up radio) What is this? This is water?
It's a mouse trap.
(holding up earphones) And this?
My grandmother's ear-muffs.
(to Dunbar) Look at them, Lieutenant. Everybody  is a clown! How do you expect to win  the war with an army of clowns?
We sort of hope you'll laugh  yourselves to death.
Schulz gives out with a big phony laugh. As he laughs his eyes fall on: The light bulb and the cord tied up in a noose. Schulz stops laughing.
Now, outside everybody, for the  blankets! Everybody out!
He herds them out. Joey is in his bunk, still wearing the Hitler mustache.
Outside! You, too!
He pushes Joey out. Alone in the barrack again, Schulz qu walks to the table, exchanges the black queens and straig out the light cord.
The men, standing in line are being issued new blankets b the two German guards.
That Schulz pig. I'll get him yet.
