You hold him. I'll slug him.
It's not Schulz. It's that stoolie.  Whoever he is, he's sure batting a  thousand.
The guy I want to talk to is Sefton.  Where's Sefton? (turns to Cookie, who  is coming up in the  line) You haven't seen Sefton, have you?
(frightened) No, I haven't.
(hurrying them along) Der Naechste!
The P.O.W.s are coming back with the blankets. Schulz is  standing at the door with radio and earphones.
(calling out to the  guards) Henkel! Krause! (to Hoffy) I'm very sorry about the mouse trap,  but the war news are very depressing  anyway.
The two German guards have entered. Schulz points at the  rolled-up volley ball net under one of the bunks.
I might as well also confiscate the  antenna.
The guards carry out the wire-roll.
American know-how!

Simultaneously, he snaps the wash line. Shaking with laug he exits. As he goes out, Cookie squeezes himself into th barrack, carrying his blanket. He starts edging towards h bunk, but Hoffy grabs him.
All right, Cookie, let's hear it:  where is Sefton?
I don't know. I told you.
He wouldn't be at the Kommandant's,  would he?
I don't know.
What did they trade him for the radio?
I don't know.
During this, they have backed him up towards his bunk.
Why don't we just look in those  footlockers?
Come on, you little stooge. Hand  over them keys.
I haven't got any keys.
Okay. Then I'll get me a key.
He grabs off a piece of iron holding up a corner of the  distillery. Meanwhile, Harry has pulled out Sefton's  footlockers. Stosh shoves the iron bar into one of the lo Stops. Looks up at Hoffy.
Okay, Hoffy?
Okay.

Stosh starts ripping off the lock. Cookie has shrunk back into the corner of his bunk. The first footlocker is cracked open. It is brimful of  cigarettes, chocolate bars, coffee, tea and sugar. Stosh pries open the second footlocker. He throws back the top: there is a dazzling assortment of cameras, binoculars,  wristwatches, beer steins, bottles of Rhine wine and a cu clock.
Of all the hoarding cruds!
Looks like Macey's basement, don't  it?
That kid's richer than my mother.
Harry has picked up the cuckoo clock. It opens, the birdi emerges and cuckoos.
Shut up!
He slaps the door shut on it. Stosh pulls from under the  binoculars a pair of silk stockings. He holds them up.
For cryin' out loud! What would he  be doing with these?
Suppose you ask me.
They turn. In the door stands Duke, breathless. He had ju come in from the Compound.
Go on, ask me! Because I got the  goods on Mister Sefton. Because this  time he didn't shake me.
He moves toward the telescope at the window.
Take a look for yourself. It'll curdle  your guts.
He swings the telescope around so it faces the Russian  Compound.
The Russian women!
They all dash towards the window and the telescope. Hoffy pushes through and looks himself, focusing the telescope.
Try the end barrack. Where the goodies  are.
Hoffy looks.
(impatiently) Come on, Hoffy! We all want to see!
Hoffy straightens up. Stosh pushes Harry away and looks  through the telescope.
(to Duke) How did he get over there?
Easy! Walked right through the gate,  past the guard. Like he was some  Kraut Field Marshal.
Stosh, looking through the telescope, has let go with a l whistle.
This is murder!

The telescope is focused on the window, revealing: A party is in progress. Sefton is the only man among some eight Russian women. He lies on a bunk, reclining like a  Sultan. The Russian women around him vie for his favor. O plays the balalaika. Another is dancing the Kazatski on t table.
The men struggle to get at the telescope. Harry jerks Sto away. Meanwhile, Blondie moves in.
(pulling Blondie off) Go play with your marbles!
Harry looks.
The stinkin' miser! Keeping all that  to himself!
Would I like to lay my hands on him!
(from the telescope) Who wants to lay their hands on him?
Blondie, Bagradian and a couple others have dashed to the footlocker, grabbed themselves some binoculars, and dash  back to the window to look.
(to Hoffy and Price) So I'm a vigilante, huh? So what are  the Barrack Officers going to do  now?
Don't worry Duke. We'll handle it  from here on in.
You better handle it fast. Before a  few more of us get knocked off.
Hoffy, boiling mad, grabs the telescope from the guys and flings it across the room. The telescope smashes against Sefton's bunk. It almost hi Cookie. He cringes back.

Sefton is coming back from the Russian compound. There ar about a dozen P.O.W.s about. He pauses at the gate until couple of P.O.W.s have moved on. Then he walks through th gate, giving the German guard a little high sign. Whistli a Russian tune, Sefton crosses toward Barrack 4.

The electric lights are burning. Sefton enters, whistling Duke slips behind him, slams the door shut, and stands th blocking the exit. Sefton stops whistling. He surveys the situation. About t five P.O.W.s stand around silently, looking at him. Hoffy Price, Harry and Stosh in the foreground.
(casually) Hi.
No answer.
Too late for chow?
No answer.

Harry looks over to Stosh. Stosh lies in his bunk, drinking what's left of the booze swiped from the distillery. He is staring at the pin-ups Grable pasted on the ceiling of his bunk.
Come on, Animal -- let's trip the  light fantastic!
Let me alone.
You're crying, Animal.
It's that song, Harry!
(seeing the pin-up) You don't want to cry over a dame  that doesn't even know you're alive!  Snap out of it!
There's a time in every man's life  when he wants to be alone! So go  away!

He takes another swig and lets down the big pin-up so it  hangs a few inches in front of his eyes. Harry turns away from Stosh, picks up a pilot cap, turns inside out so the yellow fur shows on top, puts it on. He gets some straw out of a hole in a mattress and tucks it  under the cap like curls.
All right, boys, who wants the Queen  of the May?
A P.O.W. drops his partner and dances Harry off. Sefton, in his bunk, watching Price all the time.
Any cigars left, Cookie?
No answer from Cookie.
Come on, Cookie. Get me a cigar.
Cookie doesn't move.
What's the matter? You on their team  now? You think I'm the guy?
I don't know anymore.
Sefton goes to the raided footlocker for a last tattered  cigar.

I understand how you feel, Cookie.  It's sort of rough -- one American  squealing on other Americans. Then  again, Cookie -- maybe that stoolie's  not an American at all. Maybe he's a  German the Krauts planted in this  barracks. They do this type of thing.  Just put an agent in with us -- a  trained specialist. Lots of loose  information floating around a prison  camp. Not just whether somebody wants  to escape, but what outfits we were  with and where we were stationed,  and how our radar operates. Could  be, couldn't it?
In this barracks?
Why not? Just one of the boys. Sharing  our bunks. Eating our chow. Right in  amongst the ones that beat me up.  Except that he beat hardest.
Who is it?

That's not the point, Cookie. The  point is what do you do with him?  You tip your mitt and the Jerries  pull him out of here and plant him  someplace else, like Stalag Sixteen  or Fifteen. Or you kill him off and  the Krauts turn around and kill off  the whole barracks. Every one of us.  So what do you do?
Who is it?
Sefton doesn't answer.
If you don't want to tell me, why  don't you tell Hoffy? Or Security?
Yeah. Security.
He just sits there, smoking and looking in the direction Price at the middle table. Bagradian steps up to Price, w is busy beating out the rhythm. The P.O.W. is no longer  singing.
Where's Hoffy? Why don't we get any  news about Dunbar?
Don't worry. He'll be all right.
I had to be the ham! I had to shoot  off my mouth!
Forget it. He'll be back here. They've  got no proof.
Harry seats himself on the table, tossing his curls.
(to the rhythm boys) Sweet and soft, boys. Beguile me.

Stosh in his bunk. He drains the booze from the jar, look out at the room through tear blurred eyes. He sees: Harry sitting on the table, listening to the music. He is the identical pose Betty Grable has struck in the big pin photo. Stosh's eyes go back to the big pin-up photo. He looks ba at: Harry. By now it is not Harry who is sitting there. It is Betty Grable, or rather the pin-up photo superimposed in same size as Harry. Stosh blinks his eyes. He stares some more. Delirious  happiness dawns on his face. He climbs out of his bunk an walks toward Harry, in a trance.
(to himself) Betty!... Betty!
He has reached the table, bows politely to Harry.
May I have this dance, Miss?
Why, sure!
He climbs off the table. Stosh puts his arm around very  elegantly and dances him off.
Who would've ever thought I'd be  holding you in my arms?
A peculiar expression comes over Harry's face.
Pinch me, will you? Pinch me so I'll  know I'm not dreaming.
Harry reaches up and pinches him heartily on the cheek.
Thank you, darling!
Again, a reaction from Harry as they dance on. Stosh sing few bars of I Love You with the record. His cheek is very close to Harry. He is lost in blissful romance.
Did anybody ever tell you you have  the most beautiful legs in the world?
Harry does a big take.
But it's not just those legs. It's  that nose of yours I'm crazy about.  That cute little button of a nose!
(the situation begins  to seep through) Hey, Animal! Animal!
(sweeping on madly) I've been crazy about you for years.  I've seen every picture you've ever  made six times. I'd just sit there  and never even open that popcorn  bag.
(breaking from him) Animal! Animal! Wake up!
He starts slapping his face.
Betty! Betty!
(taking off his wig) This is me, Animal! It's Harry  Shapiro!
Stosh stares at him. The truth dawns on him. He starts ba like a child. Hoffy hurries in from the compound. He is followed by Duk Marko and The Crutch.
Cut that music! Cut it! Listen!
All turn.
The S.S. Men are here to pick up  Dunbar. They're taking him to Berlin.  Looks like he's finished.
Only he ain't quite finished yet.  Blondie -- get that smudge pot. Tie  it to Steve's leg.
Blondie gets the can of smoke-powder and, as the scene  progresses, fastens it in The Crutch's empty pants' leg.
What are you going to do?
I want everybody out of here. We'll  need a lot of commotion on the  compound.
I'll get the men from the other  barracks.
(to Hoffy) You don't think you can snatch Dunbar?  Not from the S.S.?
We're sure going to make a stab at  it. You, Price and Stosh and Harry  and Blondie -- be at the north  latrine. You'll all get your posts.  Now everybody start drifting out  with Marko.
Easy, boys, easy. Disperse out there  nicely and always remember just  because the Krauts are dumb that  doesn't make them stupid.
The men start filing out through both doors quietly.
(to Blondie) Ready?
Roger.
(to Price, Stosh,  Harry and Duke) Okay. Move on.
The Crutch, Blondie, Harry and Stosh leave.
I don't know what your scheme is,  but it sounds crazy.
Maybe it's crazy, but it's better  than having Dunbar dead.
Just as you say, Hoffy. But wouldn't  it be smarter if I went out and kept  Schulz tied up?
Good.
(moving in) I wouldn't worry about Schulz. I'd  worry about Sefton. Remember me? I'm  the stoolie.
You ain't going to squeal this one,  brother.
No? Aren't you a little afraid to  turn the stoolie loose on that  compound? For a tip-off like this,  you know what the Krauts would pay?
You'll stay in this barracks and not  a peep out of you.
Okay, then. Put a guard on me. I  want you to put a guard on me. Because  if anything goes wrong out there,  this time you won't have a patsy.  Right?
Right.
So who stays with me? Maybe Joey? No --  not Joey. Wouldn't you feel safer  with Security on the job?
Okay, Price. You stay.
What about Schulz?
We'll take care of Schulz. (to the others) Come on.
They all follow Hoffy out, leaving Price and Sefton. They stand for a while looking at each other. From OFF co some WEIRD NOTES on the ocarina. Joey sits in his bunk, playing on his new sweet potato.
That's the boy, Joey. Play us a little  something. What do you want to hear,  Price? Home On The Range? Or maybe a  little Wagner?
No answer from Price.

Or how about a game of pinochle? No,  you're not a pinochle man. You're a  chess player. (moves to chess board) I haven't played since I was a kid.  Let's see -- (maneuvers the white  pieces) -- a pawn moves this way, doesn't  it? And a bishop this way? And the  queen -- every which way, doesn't  it?
Suppose you just sit down and keep  your mouth shut.
(moving about) I went to school with a guy named  Price. But that was in Boston. You're  from Cleveland, aren't you.
Yes, I'm from Cleveland.
I thought that's what you said. You're  from Cleveland. And you were with  the Thirty-sixth Bomb Group?
Thirty-fifth.
Three hundred and sixty-fifth Bomb  Squadron? Out of Chelveston?
Are you questioning me?
Just getting acquainted. Trying to  make one friend in this barracks.
Don't bother, Sefton. I don't like  you. I never did and I never will.
A lot of people say that and the  first thing you know is they get  married and live happily ever after. (goes to window) I wonder what they're trying to pull  out there?

Several hundred P.O.W.s are casually strolling about the  compound. The CAMERA MOVES TOWARDS the Administration Bui PAST an S.S. car parked on the roadway, with the motor  running. An S.S. driver stands at the car door. Harry and Stosh stand by the car, inspecting it. CAMERA MOVES ON PA the flagpole, against which leans Duke, and ON TO the por of the Administration Building: there stands Hoffy, readi the bulletin board. Only he isn't reading it. From one co of his eye he is peeking through the window into the  Kommandant's office. Suddenly he reacts to a movement ins Without turning, he gives the signal: he throws one end o his muffler around his neck. Duke, at the flagpole, gets it and throws his muffler aro his neck, thusly relaying the signal. At the car, Harry follows suit. Marko, leaning against the north latrine, catches the sig and, still facing the compound, RAPS with his knuckles on the wooden boards.

The Crutch is sitting on the wash trough. On hearing the  RAPS, Bagradian pulls up The Crutch's loose pants' leg.  Blondie strikes a match and lights the fuse on the smudge pot. Bagradian pulls down the pants' leg. They help The C off the wash trough and he hobbles out.

The Crutch is slowly hobbling toward the car, a thin wisp smoke curling up from his pants' leg. Out of the Administration Building emerge two S.S. Men,  leading Dunbar between them. Hoffy, standing at the bulle board, WHISTLES a few bars of the Air Force song. Dunbar  turns, sees Hoffy whistling. Hoffy doesn't look at him, b Dunbar senses that something is in the wind. He walks on  between the S.S. Men. As he is being led toward the car,  still some thirty feet away, P.O.W.s crowd in to watch hi The Crutch, hobbling on from the direction of the latrine is some twenty feet from the car. Duke straightens up from the flagpole casually, and start sauntering toward the car. The latrine. Blondie and Bagradian have moved out of the  latrine and stand there with Marko, watching the car. Harry and Stosh at the car. Stosh tightening the belt of coat, Harry pulling the barracks cap tight on his head. The driver of the car opens the door. The S.S. Men and Du are some eight feet away now. The Crutch, hobbling past the car, releases a string and smudge pot drops as he moves on. He barely makes it. Almo instantly, there is a belch of fire and smoke starts pour out of the smoke bomb. The wind billows the smoke across the car, rapidly envelo the S.S. Men and Dunbar. There are German SHOUTS from wit the smoke cloud. Duke, Harry, Stosh, Blondie, Bagradian, Marko and Hoffy m into the smoke from all sides. All now is lost in smoke.  Just silhouettes of men rushing about. SHOUTS, German  commands, SOUNDS of scuffling. From OFF a siren starts to sound. German guards come running from all corners of the compound into the cloud. In the goon towers, the guards wheel around their machine guns, but don't dare to shoot into the smoke. From the Administration Building storms von Scherbach,  followed by the two Lieutenants, Schulz and other guards. They dash into the smoke cloud, which starts lifting.

The smoke cloud starts to clear. At the car, the two S.S. Men and the driver stand with guns in their hands. Dunbar gone. The other P.O.W.s stand around innocently. Von Sche is screaming his head off, but his words are not heard. C PULLS BACK INTO Barracks 4, revealing Sefton and Price at the window. Sefton turns from the window, a little smile his face.
Ach so!
What did you say?
Amazing, what you can do with five  thousand ping-pong balls, isn't it?
Price is pacing. Joey starts tootling again.
(to Joey) Stop that, will you! (to Sefton) Those idiots! So they sprang Dunbar!  So what good is it? He's still in  the compound, isn't he? How long can  he last? Where can they hide him?
Where. Up Joey's ocarina. Didn't you  know?
Price looks at him.

All the P.O.W.s are formed into a line that serpentines t a desk set up on the porch of the Administration Building Light machine guns have been set up around them, the guar watching carefully. Behind the desk sit the two German  Lieutenants, and in back of them stands Schulz. Every P.O as he passes, is screened by the Lieutenants, then dogtag and faces being checked against an index of cards and  photographs on the desk.

Yeah? Where did we hide him? Nobody  knew that except Hoffy -- not one of  us -- and he wouldn't talk. It sure  drove the Krauts crazy looking for  Dunbar. They herded us all out into  the compound and put some extra  machine guns on us and gave us the  old picture check. You know, checking  our dogtags and our pans...

Pirelli, Blondie, Hoffy and Duke file by. The next in lin is Price, followed by Sefton. As Price is being checked, eyes meet Schulz's. Schulz looks at him inquisitively. Th only answer on Price's face for a split second is: "I don know". But he's got to watch himself as he is followed by Sefton. A barracks: Guards with dogs are searching under it. Another barracks: German guards throw tear gas bombs into and close the doors. The compound. All the P.O.W.s are now lined up in long li facing the Administration Building. Von Scherbach, standi on the porch flanked by the S.S. Men, his Lieutenants and Schulz, lets go with a tirade. THE CAMERA SWOOPS BACK fro his face over the lined-up P.O.W.s all the way to the sou latrine and UP AND OVER the water tank. As it now PANS IN the water tank, we see Dunbar. He is hiding in the water  tank, up to his knees in icy water. He is weak and drawn he has to hold on not to collapse.

...against their index file. They  searched under the barracks. They  searched the roofs. They even searched  the bathroom in the Kommandant's  office, but no Dunbar. Then they  tried to smoke him out, throwing  tear gas bombs into every barracks,  just in case he was hiding up in the  rafters. Then they made us stand for  six hours out there until finally  von Scherbach came out and gave us  his ultimatum: if Dunbar didn't come  out by next morning he'd raze the  whole lous; compound, stick by stick  and if we'd sleep in the mud for the  rest of our lives, that was okay by  him. I thought he'd bust his gut the  way he was screaming. He just couldn't  figure how a guy could disappear  from the compound and still be there,  but Dunbar was there all right. He  sure was there.
From the goon towers lights are sweeping over the compoun the dark barracks and the barbed wire fences.

He was there for half the night, his  feet right in the icy water. That's  tough to take, especially when you  got three heated pools at home. It  took a lot of guts, the kind you'd  expect from a sergeant -- but a  lieutenant --!
Dunbar, exhausted, is clinging desperately to the ladder  inside the tank, his feet in the icy water. Over the tank sweeps the light from a goon tower.
The Hundefuehrer is leading his dogs past the dark barrac Not a sound from within.

Blankets are hanging over the windows. On the center tabl burns a margarine lamp. All the men from Barracks 4 are  gathered around the table. All except Joey and Sefton. In the center of the table is one of the P.O.W.s' cap. The m one by one, are dropping their dogtags into it.

(putting in his own  dogtag) Let's have it understood men -- this  is going to be a rough deal. But we  have no choice. One of us must take  Dunbar out of the camp tonight. Right  away. We'll draw one dogtag and the  guy who goes with it does the job.  It's going to be rough because the  Krauts have put on extra guards and  they are expecting a move like this.  So if anyone wants to withdraw, he  better speak up now.
He looks around. Nobody moves.
Then we're all in on it?
Everybody but Joey, and you know  who.
They shoot a look towards Sefton. Sefton stands leaning  against his bunk. He looks right back at them. Back at the table.
Okay. (with irony) Who's the lucky one?
He shakes the dogtags in the cap. Everyone crowds around, tensely.
Let me do it, Hoffy.
You want to go?
No. I want to draw.
All right. (holding out cap) Draw.
Harry closes his eyes, puts his hand deep into the cap an picks out a tag. But before anybody can look at it, Price closes his fist over it.
Suppose we call this my tag. I'll  take him out.
The men turn toward Price.
No volunteers, Price. I said we're  all in on it.
You have elected me Security. The  way things have been going in this  Barracks, I guess I've done a poor  job and I want to make up for it. Is  that asking too much?
Sefton, standing against the bunk, takes it in with a gri smile.
We've all done a poor job of it.
I still say this is my tag. Any  objections, Hoffy?
Any objections, men?
Not from me.
He can have it.
(to Stosh) Who are we to argue with a hero?
How about me latching on, Price?
Three's a crowd, especially if you've  got to cut your way through barbed  wire. (hands Price wire  cutters) Here's the wire cutters. (to Blondie) Are the civilian clothes ready?
(stuffing clothes  into duffel bag) Coming up.
(to Harry and Stosh) Get going on the trap door.
They move to the old trap door and start unscrewing it. P goes to his bunk, Hoffy with him. Price starts putting on his jacket.
What do you say, Hoffy. We'll hit  the air raid trenches and cut out in  back of Barracks nine.
You'd better cut out in back of the  south latrine.
Why the south latrine?
Because that's where he is. In the  water tank.
Price takes it smoothly.
Good spot. With any luck we'll make  Krems by morning, or maybe even catch  a barge to Linz.
Sefton, who has been watching closely, tosses two packs o cigarettes on the table.
Two packs of cigarettes say Dunbar  never gets out of the compound.
You starting that again?
Anybody cover?
They all look at him.
(from the trap door) Somebody step on that crumb!
We warned you, Sefton!
Sure you warned me. You were going  to slit the throat of that stoolie.
He throws an open jack-knife onto the table. The blade st The knife quivers.
Here's the knife to do it with. Only  make sure you got the right throat.
We're looking at it.
(to Harry and Stosh) Hurry up on that trap. (to Sefton) What are you trying to do, Sefton?  Gum up the works?
That's right. Or would you rather  see Dunbar lying out there in the  mud tomorrow morning like Manfredi  and Johnson?
Look, Sefton, I had my hands full so  they wouldn't tear you apart --
I called it the last time, didn't I?
Are we going to stand around here  and listen to him until the Germans  find out where Dunbar is?
The Germans know where Dunbar is.
How do they know?
You told them, Hoffy.
Who did?
You did!
You off your rocker?
Uh-huh. Fell right on my head. (confronting Price) Sprechen sie deutsch?
No. I don't sprechen sie deutsch.
Maybe just one word? Kaput? Because  you're kaput, Price.
Will you get this guy out of my hair  so I can go?
Go where? To the Kommandant's office  and tell him where Dunbar is?
(starting for him) I'll kill you for that!

Shut up! (slaps his face) Security Officer, eh? Screening  everybody, only who screened you?  Great American hero. From Cleveland,  Ohio! Enlisted right after Pearl  Harbor! When was Pearl Harbor, Price?  Or, don't you know?
December seventh, forty-one.
What time?
Six o'clock. I was having dinner.
Six o'clock in Berlin. They were  having lunch in Cleveland. (to the others) Am I boring you, boys?
Go on.

He's a Nazi, Price is. For all I  know, his name is Preismaier or  Preissinger. Sure, he lived in  Cleveland, but when the war broke  out he came back to the Fatherland  like a good little Bundist. He spoke  our lingo so they put him through  spy school, gave him phony dogtags --
He's lying! He's just trying to get  himself off the hook!
(jabbing him) Shut up, he said.
You heard him.
Okay, Herr Preismaier, let's have  the mail box.
The what?
The one you took out of the corner  of your bunk and put in this pocket.
He snatches a black queen out of Price's coat pocket.

Now let me show you how they did it.  They did it by mail. That's right.  Little love notes between our Security  Officer and von Scherbach with Schulz  the mail man. (ties up a loop in  the light cord) Here's the flag. (opening a black queen) And here's the mail box. (grins at Price, who  is sweating) Cute, isn't it? They delivered the  mail or picked it up when we were  out of the barracks, like for Appell.  When there was a special delivery,  they'd pull a phony air raid to get  us out of here, like for instance,  last night. (to Price again) There wasn't a plane in the sky --  or was there, Price?
Price dives for the open trap door. He is caught by Duke. breaks away and flings himself at the window, tearing dow the blanket.
(screaming) Hilfe!
He never gets the whole word out. Stosh and Harry jump hi Stosh clamping his hand over his mouth. They throw him to the floor and all duck as the light from the goon tower s through the barracks.
The Hundefuehrer, leading the dogs past Barracks Nine. Th dogs sense something, and bark. The Hundefuehrer looks ar The dogs calm down and the Hundefuehrer goes on.
Everybody is petrified. The barking dies down. Blondie an Triz hang the blanket again.
(indicating Price) Gag him.
Two P.O.W.s move in and take over. Duke moves up to Sefton.
Brother, were we all wet about you!
(putting a cigar butt  into his mouth) Forget it.
He strikes a match on Duke's stubbled cheek and lights th cigar. It doesn't hurt Duke a bit. He just stands there w a broad grin.
(indicating Price) What are we going to do with him?
Don't you know? Because I got my own  ideas. (to Blondie) Let's have that civilian stuff.
Blondie gives him the barracks bag. Sefton opens it, take out a Tyrolean hat, puts it on. It is too small.
I'll look pretty stupid in this,  yodelling my way over those Alps.  Now let's have the wire cutters.
Pirelli takes them out of Price's belt and gives them to  him.
You taking Dunbar?
You betcha. There ought to be some  reward money from Mama. Say ten  thousand bucks worth.
He starts putting on his jacket and his cap, the eyes of  every P.O.W. in the barracks on him.
I told you boys I'm no escape artist,  but for the first time, I like the  odds. Because now I got me a decoy.
What's the decoy?

Price. When I go I want you to give  me five minutes. Exactly five minutes  to get Dunbar out of that water tank.  Then you throw Price out into the  compound, nice and loud. He'll draw  every light from every goon tower.  It's our only chance to cut through.  What do you say, Barracks' Chief?
Shoot!
Price squirms.
What's the matter, Price? You said  you were going to save Dunbar, didn't  you? So now, you're getting your  chance.
Sefton has picked up the barracks bag and the wire cutter and moves toward the trap door.
So long, Cookie. The department store  is all yours. What's left of it.
So long, Sefton.
You're not disposing of those Russian  broads?
Tell you what to do. First, get  yourself a hundred cigarettes for  the Kraut guards. Then get yourself  another face.
Harry laughs.
You could use a new one yourself.
Let's synchronize the watches. Eleven  forty-two, sharp.
(adjusting his) Check.
He climbs down into the open trap. All the men crowd arou to say goodbye.
One more word. If I ever run into  any of you bums on a street corner,  just let's pretend we never met  before. Understand?
He takes the cigar butt out of his mouth, puts it into Du half-open mouth -- and goes. There is a moment of silence
This barracks will never be the same.
Sefton is crawling cautiously in the direction of the lat Behind him, the trap door is being fitted into the floor  again.
Sefton has crawled to the edge of the barracks, waits for light to swoop by. Then he dashes into the latrine just i time to evade another searchlight from a goon tower.
Sefton recovers his breath, listens for a second, then cl up on the wash trough. He raps on the bottom of the water tank.

Dunbar, utterly exhausted, is clinging to the ladder, his legs submerged in the icy water. He hears the signal. The is a flicker in his eyes. He hears another signal. With h last strength, he climbs the ladder, waits for a light to swoop by, then works himself over the top.

Sefton has climbed on a beam above the wash trough. Dunba legs come down, dripping wet. Sefton gets hold of them, t as Dunbar lets go above, he takes his full weight and low him to the wash trough. Dunbar lies there, gasping.
Shut off the moaning, or we'll have  the dogs on us. Shut it off,  Lieutenant. This is orders!
My legs are frozen.
(rubbing his legs  down) You'd better get that blue blood  circulating, because we're busting  out of this stink-hole in exactly -- (looks at watch) -- one minute and twenty seconds.
(looking up) Sefton!
What did you expect, a St. Bernard  dog?
Not you.
What some brandy?
Yeah.
Who doesn't! Suppose we wait until  we hit the Waldorf Astoria.
It's on me.
You won't get off that cheap.
What are the chances busting out of  here?
(looking at his watch) We'll know in forty seconds. (then with a grin) Only in a democracy can a poor guy  get his keister shot off with a rich  guy.

Hoffy stands looking at his watch. Blondie is crossing wi the breadknife in his hand towards the door. Stosh and Du hold the gagged Price down on the bunk. Harry has strung  together some five old cans.
(to the bearded P.O.W.) Hold his leg.
The P.O.W. sits on Price's leg. Harry starts tying the ti cans to his ankle.
(to Price) Just in case your Kameraden are hard  of hearing.
Fifteen seconds. Get him up.
Stosh and Duke pull Price up off the bunk and move him to the door. He struggles and squirms.
Stop shaking, Price. There'll be no  pardon from no governor.
(to Price) Funny, ain't it? In your own Vaterland --  by your own Soldaten! (to Stosh) The kid's got no sense of humor.
What's the matter with you, Security?  You were always so calm. Especially  when you let Manfredi and Johnson go  out there. (to Blondie) Open the hatch.
Blondie has inserted the breadknife in the crack of the d He now whips up the knife with a sharp movement.
The bar across the door swivels up. The door is flung ope from inside. Duke and Stosh hold Price. Hoffy tears the g off his mouth.
Let 'er go!

Duke and Stosh have lifted Price with all their might, an give him a terrific heave. As Price comes flying out into the compound, the tin cans clattering, the door is slamme shut. A light from a goon tower swings sharply to Price and hol him in its beam. A burst of machine gun fire splatters ar him. He scrambles to his feet, screaming.
Schiesst nicht! Schiesst nicht! Ich  bin ein Deutscher!

His words are drowned out by more machine gun fire. He tr to run back towards his barracks, but is cut off by anoth beam and more machine gun fire from another goon tower. H runs madly into the dark compound, the tin cans clatterin behind him -- lights from all the goon towers searching f him.

Sefton and Dunbar stand at the door of the latrine,  searchlights swinging in arcs toward the compound. Sefton holds the wire-cutters in his hand. There is the clatter the tin cans and machine gun fire, and Price's desperate  screams, "Nicht schiessen! Nicht schiessen!".
Now!
They duck out.

Sefton and Dunbar dash across the short stretch to the ba wire. They fall on their faces at the wire and Sefton sta cutting. Price. A machine gun bullet has struck him in the shoulde He desperately tries to evade the relentless light beams. manages to tear off the tin cans, runs on towards the  Administration Building.
